story:
Our Crew says Hi!

Hello! We are a group of 8 students from RMIT Diploma of Screen and Media, and we are working to put together this short film for our major final assessment, aiming to produce a high quality production that could be also used for future film competitions/festivals :)
Just a short introduction on our various roles:
Director/Producer: Eunice Goh
Camera/Lighting/Audio Crew: Luis Duncan, Sam Reiher, Hana Okada, Jason Morsling, Ghaith Nadir, Lliam Milkins
1st AD: Chloe Burns
Main Equipments: JVC DVC 500, Black Magic Camera Kit, LED lights and Redheads. Booms and shotgun microphones
Filming Dates: 7, 8, 9 October 2016
Filming Locations: Old Melbourne Gaol, Old City Watchhouse, Hughesdale Private Apartment

Why this film?

"The Last Meal" is a story inspired by the photo project "No Seconds - Victor Feguer" by photographer Henry Hargreaves. The director (also the scriptwriter), Eunice, is deeply touched by the emotions drawn out by pure still photos of death row prisoners' last meals. Through this film, she hopes to let the audiences into the minds of death row prisoners and how they are just normal people like you and me.

How will the money be spent?

We are aiming for a total of $2000 for just one simple reason - this is the total location rental cost. The filming will be taking place at the Old Melbourne Gaol, and the rental fees are $350/hr - pretty taxing for a student really!

On top of this, we will also have other expenses, which you can see the breakdown simply in the chart below. However, we are not going to be greedy and just hope for the location expenses to be covered from this crowdfund!

Want to help but not $$$?

Hey we understand that help doesn't only comes in the form of money! If you like our production and would like to give a little hand, it will be a BIG help to us just by sharing this page and letting more people know about our project !

story:
THE FILM

Through the eyes and experiences of women activists negatively affected by coal, oil and mega-infrastructure projects No Good Comes from the Mine (working title) is a Pan-African film that focuses on communities in South Africa, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).

The women’s stories in South, West and East Africa represent the experiences of many thousands of communities across the African continent whose land, livelihoods, health and futures are being threatened and taken from them by large mining companies and their allies in governments who benefit from extractives.

In the documentary No Good Comes from the Mine we will reveal their day to day realities and how they are mobilising to resist and protest the injustices with the support of local rights organisations that share their cause and assist them to change what can literally be a life and death situation.

WoMin works alongside these national and regional movements and popular organisations of women and peasants to put forward alternatives including food rights through agro-ecology; support for the work of care and reproduction above profit; protection of nature and natural resources as common goods first; a gender just transition to renewable energy which is democratically owned and governed, with women playing a leading role. Our work will also feature in the film with our staff providing the overarching commentary, context and eco-feminist political analysis for the experiential stories and realities of the women’s lives and struggles for justice.

 

HOW THE FILM WILL BE USED

No Good Comes from the Mine will be produced in English, French and Portuguese and WoMin and our alliance partners will use it for training, political education, lobbying and advocacy.

It will cultivate greater awareness of the costs of extractives-oriented development, and it’s particularly gendered costs, amongst civil society organisations and the wider public and will be used to advocate and campaign for the needed alternatives to governments and multilateral bodies, like the African Union and the United Nations.

The film plugs into global issues and conversations so we will also reach broader audiences via film festivals, licensed broadcast and social media.

 

THEMES & APPROACH

Produced with an eco-feminist framing, our film explores thematic issues around food and land rights, consent, militarisation, violence against women and access to water. The overarching theme is fossil fuel extraction and its immediate and long-term impacts: climate change.

Our production process is participatory and feminist Ghanaian Director, Yaba Badoe, believes in character’s telling their own stories intimately and frankly. She spends at least a week in the field with the women and their families, getting to know them and understanding their realities, grappling with the issues and challenges they face and gaining insights into their day to day lives so that she can identify the best main characters to tell the community’s story and fully explore the content and visual potential before commencing filming.

 

ONE COUNTRY HAS BEEN FILMED ALREADY

We have completed the majority of filming for the first third in the Somkhele and Fuleni communities affected by coal mining in northern KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.

At Somkhele, 85 km northwest of Richards Bay, men migrate to cities and mines in search of jobs while women work the land and raise their families alone.

To maximise profits in the face of a commodity crisis, Somkhele’s Petmin scaled up operations just one month before we started filming - this in a context of severe drought, the worst in more than 30 years. The mine, which started operations in 2008, has encroached on more farming land and deepening already intolerable social and environmental impacts. Large clouds of coal dust cause health problems for residents and cattle, hampering farming and exacerbating the discomfort and devastation the mine is wreaking on their once peaceful lives. 

Local resident, Ntombiyenkosi Mngomezulu says: “We’re not living well here. There’s lots of dust. At night we can’t sleep with the sound of the machines.” And beyond the torment of the machine noise, the blasting cracks their houses.

Despite the fact that the area has been declared a disaster zone due to the prevailing drought, in March 2016 the mine announced that it would start to exploit underground water aquifers to maintain its operations. The mine uses vast water resources to wash their coal in preparation for export whilst women walk up to 25 kilometres to access drinking water. “They arrived and blocked our rivers so we can’t fetch water. Right now we don’t have water. We buy water.” says Smangele Nkosi of Somkhele.

In nearby Fuleni, Ibutho Coal wants to open a new mine so women from Fuleni visit Somkhele on a fact finding mission. Khipile Msweli of Somkhele tells them that "nothing good has come from the mine". Smangele Nkosi warns the women of Fuleni to resist the development of the mine at all costs saying that at first the mine will promise you beautiful things so that you agree but won’t honour any of their promises. The women were promised jobs for the community but say that not one person in their community has been employed.

Those who challenge the mine or the community and traditional leaders who sold them out face violent intimidation and threat. The Petmin mine management have also mobilised workers, most of whom originate outside of the locality, against dissenting community members.

Their struggle is ongoing as community groups continue to protest mining operations and the negative impacts. But there is renewed hope for the Somkhele and Fuleni communities. The South African Human Rights Commission is holding public meetings with communities affected by coal mines to gather information about how human rights are being violated. Fuleni and Somkhele were selected for research to build a strong report on the issue.

To ensure the film remains current during production of the second and third segments in Uganda and DRC, a local film maker will cover important events and the Global Environmental Trust will also share their relevant footage. The Women’s Water Assembly in KwaZulu-Natal and the Somkhele women’s testimony to the People’s Tribunal against Corporate Impunity in Swaziland were covered in August 2016.Watch our powerful fund raising trailer on this site that draws on the Somkhele and Fuleni footage.

NOW WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT TO FILM IN UGANDA IN MARCH 2017

We have already raised the majority of funding required to film this second part of the film but need this final $10 000 to keep to the shooting schedule and allow for enough time in the field with the resilient women resisting the effects oil drilling is having on their day to day struggle to put food on the table and save their land from environmental devastation.

The Focus for Filming in Uganda

Oil drilling activity in the Western Albertine rift area of Uganda has been escalating since 2006 and women and children are bearing the brunt of the impact.

The Ugandan part of No Good Comes from the Mine focuses on the oil industry’s devastating impact on access to land and food sovereignty, and community well-being and safety. These impacts are deeply gendered because women make up 76% of the workforce producing food for domestic consumption.

All land in the Albertine region belongs to individuals or is communally owned yet oil companies and government don’t negotiate with community members for oil activities, and where there is negotiation at all, women are not involved because they do not have rights to own land.  There have also been many cases where men have received compensation money for land on behalf of their families and run away with it to the cities leaving their wives and children stranded without land or an income.

The oil fields are also highly militarised and securitised and women have reported being sexually harassed, stripped and even raped collecting firewood and water in the areas they once occupied and used.

A lack of transparency exists in oil licenses information and communities have not participated in Environmental Impact Assessments. So it is in this context that there is growing urgency for women’s voices to be heard and amplified in oil debates and for the support of demonstration gardens and indigenous seed exchange and sharing programmes spearheaded by women.

The main characters in No Good Comes from the Mine will be women from the Buliisa oil area, Kigaga Oil Refinery Affected Association, and Kwataniza Women Farmer's Group led by dynamic rights activists Beatrice Rukanyanga, Kagole Margaret, Jessica Buteraba and Alice Musimenta.

The film will also focus on the Rwamutonga community where an estimated 500 families of over 2000 people have been dispossessed of their land and access to forests and water bodies by oil drilling and are now located in resettlement camps.

The women will tell their stories about the challenges they face and how they manage them, revealing how they are mobilizing to counter the drilling companies, government structures, patriarchal leaders and men in their communities who are violating their rights. They will also express their vision of a ‘good life’ and what they expect from their government.

WoMin and the film’s director, Yaba Badoe, will make the Uganda part of the film in collaboration with The National Association of Professional Environmentalists (NAPE). It will show how these two organisations and the National Association for Women's Action in Development, Kakindo Orphans Care and the Gaia Foundation work with the women to help them survive, resist and effect change.

Their work with local and national organisations conducting research, supporting local alternatives around food, water and energy, and building a broad coalition to advance macro-economic development alternatives to the dominant extractives driven plan will also feature in the film where it is relevant to the women’s stories.​

The existing fundraising trailer focusing on the South African part of the film will be updated to include the Uganda story.
 

FUTURE FILMING IN DRC & POST-PRODUCTION

Any additional funds raised in this campaign will go towards crew, equipment and travel costs for our third and final stage of filming in the DRC where the Inga mega hydropower scheme is threatening the lives and livelihoods of thousands of people.

Filming in DRC is planned for June/July 2017. 

We will be raising the production budget of $36 000 for filming in DRC and the post-production budget of $40 000 via traditional organisational fundraising channels and film funds. If necessary, we will run two additional Indiegogo campaigns to complete fundraising for the production budget for the final stage of filming in DRC and to cover post-production costs. 

Post-production is scheduled to start in August 2017 with transcriptions, translations and edit preparation of footage from the final phase of filming in DRC and editing in October and November 2017.

 

HOW TO SUPPORT US

We really need help to get this film made, and anything you can do to support it is great.

Contribute whatever you can. Any amount helps! Challenge others to make a contribution.

Spread the word. We want to raise awareness, not just money, but awareness may help us raise money!  So please let people know about our campaign.

Link to our Twitter network

Like us on Facebook

Visit our website

Email us: africanwomin@gmail.com

Send everyone you know the LINK to our Indiegogo page.

Buy into our Perks.

Thank you for your support!

 

THE IMPACT

The negative impacts of extractives on people and the environment is a global issue. Big mining companies are exploiting natural resources at the expense of local communities East and West, North and South with impunity. It can be stopped but only if we work together to help women in exploited communities to rise up and change their situation.  

Your contribution will make a very real difference in helping thousands of women in communities across Africa and the world mobilise against exploitative extractives and the effects of climate change.

From our experience, the best thing about making a documentary that will be used for training and advocacy is the ongoing usage. It’s rewarding to know that beyond the initial film festival runs and broadcasts, that the French, Portuguese and English versions of this film will be used by organisations across the world to effect change and save lives for years to come.

THE TEAM

Yaba Badoe - Film Director

Yaba Badoe is an award-winning Ghanaian-British documentary film maker and writer with many years’ experience in broadcast television. She trained with the BBC and has made arts and culture based documentaries for the main terrestrial channels in the UK.  

In 2003 she directed a one hour documentary about the life and work of Nobel Laureate, Toni Morrison, for BBC4.  In 2010, Yaba set up Fadoa Films, through which she’s made The Witches of Gambaga, winner of the Best Documentary Award 2010 at the Black International Film Festival in Britain, and 2nd Prize, Documentaries 2011 at FESPACO. In 2014 she completed The Art of Ama Ata Aidoo about the life and work of iconic, African feminist writer, Ama Ata Aidoo and was nominated for a Distinguished Woman of African Cinema Award by the Women Filmmakers of Zimbabwe.

She acknowledges that her recent documentaries could not have been made without the support of the women’s movement in Ghana and internationally. Netright, an association of women’s organisations in Ghana uses The Witches of Gambaga to campaign to prevent violence against women believed to be witches. The film is shown to every student at the University of Ghana in the hope that they will question age-old religious beliefs that associate women’s sexuality with the dark arts. In Western Kenya, where there is a high incidence of witch burning, Amnesty International uses the film to raise awareness of human rights.

Her passion is to tell women’s stories in a way that allows them to speak for themselves. At the same time, she thinks it’s crucial to situate her subjects in a social and economic context, so that everyone watching her films begins to understand the gender regimes that shape and constrain women’s lives in Africa. Her aim is to inform, educate and generate empathy to change a status quo that often sensationalises and patronises women from non-Western cultures.

Sharon Farr - Film Producer 

Sharon has produced, directed, researched and scripted hundreds of hours of factual programming across the actuality genres over the past 23 years. She has worked extensively in Africa and runs South African company Shoot the Breeze Productions with Lee Otten.

Her work has received numerous local and international awards including World Awards at the Asia Media Summit for the Best Documentary Promoting Religious Understanding and Tolerance with Good Vibrations and Best Documentary on HIV for Masindy’s Story as well as a SAFTA for Best Magazine Show with the mind body spirit series Free Spirit.

A career highlight was making the documentary feature Love, Communism, Revolution & Rivonia: Bram Fischer’s Story that was voted Best South African Documentary at the Encounters Festival in 2007.

She has a passion for human rights issues and telling positive and inspiring African stories that effect change. She loves the collaborative nature of filmmaking and it’s the creative interplay between content and visuals when shooting and editing that excites her most.

Melania Chiponda, Regional Campaign Coordinator, WoMin

Melania has expertise in movement building, action oriented research and development of advocacy strategies. She has vast experience working with grassroots women affected by mineral resource extraction and has worked with a leading grassroots movement in Zimbabwe which represents women and communities impacted by mining induced involuntary displacements.

Her research and advocacy work engages with global extractive industries from the perspective of grassroots women that are directly affected by mining, and is embedded in a participatory action research approach. An overarching theme of her research involves women’s land rights, environmental and climate justice. Melania has vast experience supporting grassroots women’s efforts to take creative advocacy actions, and she took a leading role in raising the profile of violence against women in the extractives industry through diverse strategies. Melania holds an MSc in Development Studies from Women’s University in Africa.

Samantha Hargreaves - Regional Director, WoMin

Samantha Hargreaves is a land, agrarian and extractive industry specialist, promoting analysis and organising by women in South Africa and the rest of the continent. She has been employed by organisations fighting domestic violence, promoting landless peoples’ rights, building international anti-poverty social movements and addressing problems caused by mining and petroleum industries. She has served social movements as a field worker, researcher, campaigner and programme manager and in 2013, co-founded the WoMin (Women in Mining) African Gender and Extractives Alliance where she his is currently the director. Samantha holds a master’s degree in Development Studies from the University of the Witwatersrand and is an associate of the Wits Society Work and Development Institute.

Maggie Mapondera - Communications, Solidarity & Alliance-building Coordinator, WoMin

Maggie has supported feminist movements across Southern Africa and around the world for over 7 years, facilitating creative ways to document human experience as well as struggles for justice. As an intern at the Refugee Law Project in Uganda, Maggie facilitated an urban narratives project with women refugees in Kampala, seeing the efficacy of powerful personal stories in advocacy work.

She volunteered with Zimbabwean refugees and asylum-seekers in South Africa as an intern for PASSOP (People Against Suffering, Suppression, Oppression and Poverty), spent a summer doing Theatre for Social Change in Swaziland, and volunteered as a translator and assistant editor on a Voice of Witness title, Hope Deferred: Narratives of Zimbabwean Lives (McSweeneys, 2010).

She also worked at Just Associates (JASS), a global feminist movement building organisation committed to amplifying the voice and visibility of women human rights defenders and their movements worldwide. Maggie graduated from Yale with a BA in Comparative Literature, focusing on African literatures in French and English.

She has vast experience working with grassroots women affected by mineral resource extraction and has worked with a leading grassroots movement in Zimbabwe which represents women and communities impacted by mining induced involuntary displacements.Her research and advocacy work engages with global extractive industries from the perspective of grassroots women that are directly affected by mining, and is embedded in a participatory action research approach. An overarching theme of her research involves women’s land rights, environmental and climate justice. Melania has vast experience supporting grassroots women’s efforts to take creative advocacy actions, and she took a leading role in raising the profile of violence against women in the extractives industry through diverse strategies. Melania holds an MSc in Development Studies from Women’s University in Africa.Samantha Hargreaves - Regional Director, WoMinSamantha Hargreaves is a land, agrarian and extractive industry specialist, promoting analysis and organising by women in South Africa and the rest of the continent. She has been employed by organisations fighting domestic violence, promoting landless peoples’ rights, building international anti-poverty social movements and addressing problems caused by mining and petroleum industries. She has served social movements as a field worker, researcher, campaigner and programme manager and in 2013, co-founded the WoMin (Women in Mining) African Gender and Extractives Alliance where she his is currently the director. Samantha holds a master’s degree in Development Studies from the University of the Witwatersrand and is an associate of the Wits Society Work and Development Institute.Maggie Mapondera - Communications, Solidarity & Alliance-building Coordinator, WoMinMaggie has supported feminist movements across Southern Africa and around the world for over 7 years, facilitating creative ways to document human experience as well as struggles for justice. As an intern at the Refugee Law Project in Uganda, Maggie facilitated an urban narratives project with women refugees in Kampala, seeing the efficacy of powerful personal stories in advocacy work.She volunteered with Zimbabwean refugees and asylum-seekers in South Africa as an intern for PASSOP (People Against Suffering, Suppression, Oppression and Poverty), spent a summer doing Theatre for Social Change in Swaziland, and volunteered as a translator and assistant editor on a Voice of Witness title, Hope Deferred: Narratives of Zimbabwean Lives (McSweeneys, 2010).She also worked at Just Associates (JASS), a global feminist movement building organisation committed to amplifying the voice and visibility of women human rights defenders and their movements worldwide. Maggie graduated from Yale with a BA in Comparative Literature, focusing on African literatures in French and English.

story:
Who Are We?

Justin Dray(IMDB) is an actor/writer that lives in Los Angeles. He has produced everything from feature films to short web content. Some of his favorite credits include 'Still the King', 'It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia', 'Zach Stone is Gonna be Famous', and 'Heroes'.

Parisa Fakhri is an actor/writer living in Los Angeles as well. She originally hails from Texas, by way of Iran. She has a successful commercial and television career. 

What's The Story?

Our series is a playful situational, character driven comedy where the two main partners in crime but not in life, Parisa and Justin, create, produce, and perform in a weekly variety show. The series is a combination of stage show, backstage antics and the daily lives of these misfits. Often, our heroes biggest foils are themselves, finding out who they are and how to work together is always ridiculous and challenging, but ultimately rewarding in this off beat world.

With Your Help.

With your help and support, we will be able to shoot and produce 15 episodes of our web series. This exposure will enable us to get our idea out to masses in hopes of getting it produced as a television show!

Follow the $$$

We are asking for $20,000 to produce 15, 3-5 minute episodes. Minus the %'s taken for the campaign, that breaks down to about  $1200 per episode. All money will go to paying cast and crew, feeding cast and crew, equipment rentals, location costs, costumes, props, post production, marketing and insurance for the production. If we do not reach our entire goal, we will still use every dollar to shoot as much as we can!

A Loan?

Our unique take on this campaign is that we would actually love to be able to give you guys your money back. Our goal is to shop it to networks and if we get a tv deal...

 We will return all of your monies!

story:
We've all had dreams of becoming a Ghostbuster; I know I have personally since childhood. My name is {} and I am putting together a series that is a continuation of the original films, instead of a remake. With the recent film, many still have ghosts on the brain, but need something they can really set their proton packs to. Where are our characters now and how have the previous interactions changed the public's perception of Ghostbusters as whole? How have the ones who came after our original four shaped the company and what challenges (or lack of, initially) must they overcome? That's what I want to discover and I need you to help get us there.

Contributing to our series will earn you placement among the ranks of all our Ghostbusters.

 

Our story begins in a new pilot city for Ghostbusters INC. as they begin to unveil a new city wide service to cleanse recently deceased locations in conjunction with police and paramedics. This enables them to capture any lingering spiritual presences before they may become a problem. If all goes well, more and more cities will begin to adopt the process.

SIGN UP THE FIRST WEEK AND READ THE FIRST EPISODE SCRIPT!

All of the current shareholders gather to sign off on the initiative following the death of Dr. Egon Spengler and some voice their concerns about the projection of their company. Even with the new tech and streamlined Ghostbusters in the field, many feel as if they have only become another looked down on service like trash men from what they once were. Upon further inspection, Gary Spengler, the late Dr's son, notices an increase in capacity of their stored specters. That's when all hell breaks loose due to a Portable Poltergeist that is set loose in the office. With these still fresh spirits never having a chance to take a form or to be bound to a location are set loose, the entire city comes to life and it's up to the new team to reclaim it.

 

​Anyone can go outside and film a video - all it takes is a camera. We want to bring a cinematic episodic series to the fans of Ghostbusters; something we would all geek over ourselves. The only catch is many of these wonderfully talented individuals prepared to work on this series still have full time jobs and other responsibilities, so the incentive of being paid for their work will only bring out the best overall. No one person can do this all. Many included are our principal actors, crew members, digital VFX artists, 3D animation team, music composers, film editors and on set special effects & pyrotechnics.

 

There's also many production costs including securing locations, costuming, building and maintaining props, hair and makeup, craft service for our long filming days and of course all the equipment rentals needed to bring the professional edge to this series.

Many of the hired artists for this project have never had the opportunity for paid work in a field many of them have devoted time and dollar towards. All it takes is one influential viewer to hire these astoundingly talented people I have the honor of working with.

Should the funding not reach intended goals, (with the backers expressed permission), we are still ready pre-production wise to begin filming the first episode and go from there.

 

With any self proclaimed 'Fan Film', studios and rights holders may be pressed to shut down and nullify any work outside of their control. I would first like to mention that this film shall not make a single penny outside of the funding campaign. The funds accumulated through this project will all be spent on the project. Period. When completed, the series will be available to the public for viewing. This is a passion project we all want to do right.

The biggest thing we want to prove is how easy it can be to take a successful franchise and add another facet without completely starting over from scratch.

 

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Share this project with others, get the word out. The more people who see this the more likely it can come to fruition. We all want and need another great Ghostbusters!

Like and Share us on Facebook!
https://www.facebook.com/ghostbusterstng/

story:
Background of the movie

The original idea of ​​this film emerged from a true story where a group of young people wanted to pursue their dream by emigrating to the United States. Unfortunately, only one person survived.

Caught by this story, the main actor and his production team wanted to produce a movie to honor all people who are trying to get ahead and follow their dreams no matter what the sacrifice is.

A paradise can turn into flames. This phrase describes the genre of the film. Despite being a fiction movie, it is based on three true stories and is best described as a comedy, action and martial arts film.
The film exposes the culture and the beauty of the cities of the Caribbean countries such as Cuba, Curacao and Aruba. In addition, some parts of the movie take place in United States and The Netherlands.   

Short Summary

Ricardo, a Cuban native and martial artist feels the need to emigrate to the United States to pursue his dreams to achieve a better life for himself and his family. During this journey to the United States, he loses five friends at sea. Ricardo is the only survivor and has been picked up by a yacht heading to Curacao, The Dutch Antilles.

Upon his arrival at the island, Ricardo searches for a job in which he can earn enough money to help support his family in Cuba. In his desperate need and naive choice of making easy money, he gets involved with a gang of extortionists who wrongly accuse him of stealing from them. This forces him to immediately flee to Cuba. His pursuers follow him and try to not only extort him, but also his family. 
Ricardo wants to know who is responsible for those actions. He returns to Curacao to take revenge on the real culprit. Only the strong, like Ricardo, can sufficiently overcome all these setbacks. 

 

Actor: Abelardo Destrade Mora

The main character Ricardo is played by Abelardo Destrade Mora, who was born and raised in Cuba. He is an engineer in computer science and a master in three different martial arts styles. He also has a black belt in karate, taekwondo, judo, military art and wing chun. In Cuba, he fought in 27 fights, as a military arts specialist, without any defeat.
Abelardo is one of the first in the world in the specialty of Wing Chun and the first one of introducing this Chinese martial arts style in Curacao. Besides this, he is also the first person that introduced exercises with two knives for the wooden dummy.

What We Need & What You Get
We would like to accomplish this great movie, and for that we really need your support and spread the word about this project. Your contribution will help to finish the whole film project. All contributions to the campaign “Paradise on fire” will go towards:

  • Actors/cast
  • technical equipment and team
  • laboratory process
  • camera and light equipment
  • director & production co-workers
  • trips to different locations and countries
  • scenography
  • sound process
  • special effects
  • postproduction
  • music
  • Insurance

See the information about the different perks to see what you get in return and as an appreciation for the contribution.

Other Ways You Can Help
Help us to get the word out and talk as much as possible about this campaign to as many people  as you know. Don't forget to share this on social media and by the Indiegogo sharing tools!

story:
What This Is

"The Back Room" is an undergraduate thesis film at Boston University about a man with an addiction to pornography, and how this addiction affects his life. We're taking the skills we've learned over the past three years at BU and combining them into one larger production.

Our project will be filmed at the end of November, with a rough cut assembled mid-December to present to the Film Department faculty. We'll then spend the next semester polishing the film in post-production, and will present to the BU community in May.

We really appreciate your support! Check out our perks on the right side of the page, and if you would like to help us out, click on "get this perk."

What We Need

In order to make this film happen, we need to raise $1,500. Here's where that money is going:

  • Locations: we need to rent a suburban ranch-style house for Harold's home, and get back and forth from Boston to the set.
  • Production Design: we need to dress the set to look like Harold lives there, and doesn't take good care of his home. We also need tons of other props, such as a chicken to burn and some toys to play with.
  • Craft Services: a full crew is a happy crew! Because we're filming in a distant location, we need to feed and house our cast and crew during the weekend of shooting.

Who We Are

We are student and alumni filmmakers from Boston University's College of Communication!

Alicia Jade, Director: Alicia (ə-lee-see-ə) has been directing films since she was four years old and labeled herself the "corrector" in a production of "The Hungry Caterpillar" she was filming with her brother. She's been working on this project since May and is already so happy with how much it has grown and evolved. Her education at BU in the Film/TV program has prepared her for this film, which she hopes to be her biggest challenge yet.

Mike Damiano, Producer: Mike is a senior at BU studying Film/TV and Journalism, training for the independent film world in Boston as a producer or an editor. His work in live events and sports broadcasting brings a strong logistical background to his film projects, and he is very excited to work in the New England film community after graduating.

Erika Nardi, Editor & Graphic Designer: Erika is a senior at Boston University's College of Communication studying Film/TV and minoring in Computer Science. Although she enjoys all aspects of production, post-production is her favorite and her interests include editing and VFX. She has loved her time in Boston and is very excited to continue her education in Los Angeles next semester.

Andrew Evans, Sound Designer

Marcedes Bigham, Writer & Script Supervisor: Marcedes is a second year screenwriting graduate student at Boston University. She attended Oklahoma City University where she published several screenplay excerpts, and wrote short film After Hours. Imaginary, her third short film, is in production. The Back Room will be Marcedes’ fourth short film, and her first in Boston.

Jared Brill, Director of Photography: Jared is a junior in Boston University’s Film/TV program. Since childhood, he’s had a passion for filmmaking and visual storytelling. He has worked as DP for several short films and numerous music videos, where he brings a strong technical background and creativity into the projects.

Kendra Long, Production Designer: Kendra is a freelance production designer and art department researcher. She graduated from Boston University in 2012 with a degree in Film/TV, and has been working in the industry ever since. Previous work has included 'Black Mass' and 'Second Chance.' She is most looking forward to revisiting Production III with some professional experience under her belt and hopefully some amount of perspective.

    The Impact

    "All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way." –Tolstoy

    We are making this film for the unhappy families - to raise awareness about addiction and family issues in general. Too often in films, these topics pushed aside in favor of others that may be more entertaining or easy to watch. We want to bring attention to these issues and–although it is true that no unhappy family is alike–maybe create something that a few of those unhappy families will be able to identify with.

    Risks & Challenges

    As with any film project, we expect there will be twists and turns in the process. Here're some of the challenges we might see:

    • One weekend of shooting: because of academic and cast schedules, we are trying to shoot our entire 12-page film in one weekend. To make that weekend as smooth as possible, we're planning out each shooting day as efficiently as possible, so that when the time comes we can spend as little time as possible on logistics, and maximize our filming time.
    • Location booking: our film takes place in a small suburban home, which are few and expensive in the Boston area. So, we're looking for locations outside of Boston that will be cheaper and allow our cast and crew to stay overnight, so we can create the setting we're looking for.
    • Raising enough money: thesis films are expensive! The amount of money that we raise will affect how much we can spend on production design and special equipment, as well as how many festivals we're be able to submit to.

story:
A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST  

What is "A Beautiful Request?" A job offer? A proposal? A cry from the existential abyss? Perhaps even a cruel manipulation (making the aforementioned title, darkly ironic)?  Perhaps all of these things. 

A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST follows the moving story of a  lost young man, William, who finds himself in a dilemma with his best friend Rick, a famous playwright, calling into question his conscience, love, sexuality and dignity in the face of mortality.   Featuring a slew of fresh faces in front of the camera, hot talent behind and the experience of Robert Chuter, the award-winning film and theatre director at the helm,

A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST is a short film adapted from Alex Broun's acclaimed one man play HALF A PERSON: MY LIFE AS TOLD BY THE SMITHS which has been produced a number of times throughout Australia and the United Kingdom.  

A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST deals with the complex intricacies of human relationships, that are loaded with the power to strengthen or destroy. 

FAT KID FILMS 

Fat Kid Films is an Australian independent production company founded by Robert Chuter and Christopher Pender in 2009.   We are uniquely placed in the independent film industry as our focus lies on European-style, risk-taking and progressive projects free from the restraints often associated with full scale films and funding bodies.  A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST is a challenging, emotive,  thoughtful and most of all - unique film.  It is more about breaking the mould, producing outside the square and we invite you to be part of it by supporting and helping our film. 

This is our second venture into feature films after successfully producing our internationally acclaimed feature film THE DREAM CHILDREN .     The film is currently screening on the international film circuit and has been officially selected in over seven international festivals.  

Please see the links below to view the Netherlands, German and Australasian trailers:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EeH6px4Nt3U

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kCrCTfRauEc

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eyO1-iSZYck

THE TEAM

ALEX BROUN - writer - www.alexbroun.com

Broun, currently based in Dubai, has enjoyed considerable success in Australian  theatre, television and film as a writer, actor and director and worked extensively as an activist for refugee rights. One of the world’s leading ten minute playwrights, Broun has had over 100 ten minute plays produced in over 1500 productions in more than 40 countries globally and his plays have been translated into many languages. His plays have been workshopped and developed by the Sydney Theatre Company, Playwriting Australia and the Australian National Playwright’s Conference as well as being a former winner of the Sydney Theatre Company Young Playwright’s Scheme.  HALF A PERSON: MY LIFE AS TOLD BY THE SMITHS was first produced by Fly-On-The-Wall Theatre at FEAST in Adelaide in 2006 and at the Newtown Theatre in Sydney in September 2007. The play was then re-staged by Fly-On-The-Wall Theatre at Melbourne’s Chapel off Chapel in May 2010. It then returned for an encore season the same year and venue before being performed at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2012. That production transferred to the Kings Head Theatre in London and also in November 2014, NOVEMBER SPAWNED A MONSTER, the companion piece to HALF A PERSON was produced at Sydney’s The Old Fitzroy Theatre.  Broun has received funding from Screen Australia to develop a script based on the sinking of the SIEV X and his fifty-minute feature CLEAN TIME which received Script Development funding. Broun’s plays include: JUST ONCE, THE JACARANDA TREE, VICIOUS STREAKS, 10,000 BEERS, TRUTH BEAUTY AND A PICTURE OF YOU, DESIRE, PICK UPS, THE PRINCE OF BRUNSWICK EAST and numerous others. 

ROBERT CHUTER - director 

Award winning director/producer Chuter is not a person prone to making conventional art forms and his acclaimed works have earned him a reputation as a distinctive director. He is a director who is constantly testing his audience and his unique style has given audiences (both nationally and internationally) over 250+ complex, controversial and visually stunning productions in both theatre and film. He attended Victoria College for the Arts - School of Drama and in 1981 was trainee director at the Queensland Theatre Company. Some of his vast catalogue of stage work includes LA MIRACLE DE LA ROSE, HEIGHTS, LOVING FRIENDS, LADY CHATTERLEY’S LOVER, THE DEATH OF PETER PAN, THE HIVE, ALMOST, THE OBJECT OF DESIRE, DIMBOOLA, THIEVING BOY/LIKE STARS IN MY HANDS, ALL I WILL EVER BE, HOMME FATALE, NOVEMBER SPAWNED A MONSTER and HALF A PERSON: MY LIFE AS TOLD BY THE SMITHS. Upon returning to Melbourne he was accepted into the prestigious Swinburne Film and Television School along side such alumni as John Hillcoat, Paul Goldman, Richard Lowenstein, Clayton Jacobson, Jonathan M. Shiff, Andrew Dominik, Aleksi Vellis, Don Percy and Tony Ayers . In 1982, he won the AAV Australia Award - Best Production for his short film THE MORTAL COIL and a Green Room Award - Best Production for his cult stage production of IN ANGEL GEAR. He has produced numerous short films including KILLER ZOMBIES (St. Kilda Film Festival), XOS: A CRY FOR HELP, TAX, LETTING GO and IN FROM THE SEA.  Chuter's films include CHANGE (1983), IN DER NACHTLUFT (2001), COME SAID THE BOY (2010) and THE DREAM CHILDREN (2015).

RUDI SIIRA  - cinematographer - www.rudisiira.com

Siira is an Australian cinematographer, currently based in Melbourne. Projects range from films, documentaries, music videos and more. He gained a Diploma in Screen (Film and Television) at WA College of Art Media and Design and is an active member of the Australian Cinematographers Society.  His short films include THE WAY HOME, PLACE TO BE, SOULS, TWO LIVES (Official Selection 2015 Cannes Short Film Corner), MR. STOWLICKER (Nominated for Best Cinematography at the 2014 Ohio Indie Gathering Film Festival), TAVERN FEVER (Bronze Palm Award at the 2012 Mexico International Film Festival) and PLUME (Nominated for Best Cinematography at 2013 Melbourne 48hour Film Festival), NEIGHBOURHOOD WARS and FOR THE LOVE OF DOG. Siira's documentaries include THE COLOUR OF LOVE, MEET + EAST and ON THE LINE.

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE USED

Fat Kid Films have raised a minimal amount of the budget independently though private investment or donation, sponsorships, goods and services services.   We are seeking $3,500 to ensure that the film will be realised. 

We understand how difficult it is in these times to ask people to part with there hard earned money which is why you can donate as little as $10 to be part of the film and feel pleased that you support and ensure this uniquely drawn film be realised. 

As you will see our limited budget of $3,500 is extremely low for a short film, and every cent is accounted for.  Where we are stretched on the budget is the catering. A well fed crew is a happy crew and we very much need to cater for these people, who will be working long hours for very little reward. Without the support of Film Victoria and Screen Australia, independent films run the risk of collapsing without some philanthropic assistance from generous organisations and companies interested in supporting the film industry.

It is very valuable for the film if you share our film's journey with your friends, family, colleagues and through other social media platforms.   Please share this crowd funding page and spread the word using Indiegogo's sharing tools.

Like Page: https://www.facebook.com/hiddenwellmovie/

Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/hiddenwell2016/

With much gratitude.
story_txt: A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST  What is "A Beautiful Request?" A job offer? A proposal? A cry from the existential abyss? Perhaps even a cruel manipulation (making the aforementioned title, darkly ironic)?  Perhaps all of these things. A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST follows the moving story of a  lost young man, William, who finds himself in a dilemma with his best friend Rick, a famous playwright, calling into question his conscience, love, sexuality and dignity in the face of mortality.   Featuring a slew of fresh faces in front of the camera, hot talent behind and the experience of Robert Chuter, the award-winning film and theatre director at the helm,A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST is a short film adapted from Alex Broun's acclaimed one man play HALF A PERSON: MY LIFE AS TOLD BY THE SMITHS which has been produced a number of times throughout Australia and the United Kingdom.  A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST deals with the complex intricacies of human relationships, that are loaded with the power to strengthen or destroy. FAT KID FILMS Fat Kid Films is an Australian independent production company founded by Robert Chuter and Christopher Pender in 2009.   We are uniquely placed in the independent film industry as our focus lies on European-style, risk-taking and progressive projects free from the restraints often associated with full scale films and funding bodies.  A BEAUTIFUL REQUEST is a challenging, emotive,  thoughtful and most of all - unique film.  It is more about breaking the mould, producing outside the square and we invite you to be part of it by supporting and helping our film. This is our second venture into feature films after successfully producing our internationally acclaimed feature film THE DREAM CHILDREN .     The film is currently screening on the international film circuit and has been officially selected in over seven international festivals.  Please see the links below to view the Netherlands, German and Australasian trailers:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EeH6px4Nt3Uhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kCrCTfRauEchttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eyO1-iSZYckTHE TEAMALEX BROUN - story:
Angora Road is a 6-7 minute short film on the subject of military deployment.The film's goal is to pay respect to those who have lost family and loved ones during the call of duty.

This film exceeds far beyond your typical drama or romance story. It dives deep into the emotions and strength that is endured while coping with the loss of a loved one.

 

Justin Melson - Director, Writer, Producer

Justin is known for his short films, training videos, and equipment reviews. He is the host and creator of the Happyfox Productions YouTube channel where he has produced over a dozen short films. Justin also travels around the country producing shows that air on FOX Sports, NESN, and various other television networks.

See a few frame grabs of Justin's previous work!

Daniel Williams - Director of Photography

Daniel is an up and coming passionate cinematographer in Los Angeles who's work has taken him all over the world. His clients include Hasbro, Marvel, Star Wars, and Disney.

See a few frame grabs of Daniel's previous work!

Jacob A. Cadmus - Composer

Jacob is an extremely talented musician with a great ear for music. His work has been heard and complimented by millions online. Justin and Jacob have a previous work history together which will only strengthen the collaboration for Angora Road.

Check out one of Jacob's original scores here!

Alison Mercado - Art Director

Alison is an artist in a variety of contexts, but her focus has been in production design. She has collaborated with a variety of Las Vegas art galleries and her interior design internship.

Check out some of Alison's work here!

We have interviewed over 8 different military personnel from veterans to active duty to try to understand their mindset, experiences, and thoughts about being in the military. This has really helped our team understand more about being in their shoes.

This campaign allows us to gain the funding that we otherwise wouldn't be able to attain ourselves (or at least it would take a very long time.) Everyone on board this project is either a working professional or an aspiring professional in their field.

For the filmmaker who wants to learn from our failures and successes!

If you want to live the on set experience in person, this perk is for you!

(travel and lodge not included)

Our top perk for our top title! We would be honored to have your name credited in Angora Road's credits as an "EXECUTIVE PRODUCER".

  • After it's film festival run, the film will ultimately end up on the Happyfox Productions YouTube channel where our films average between 15,000 - 300,000 views. It is our hope that this film can be seen by the masses and spread a message that military families and families everywhere can treasure.

  • Should we not reach our funding goal, the money that is raised through the campaign will still be put towards the production, we won't run off with it and you never see a final film. We would only have to make a few compromises in terms of which camera and lenses are used, locations we will be filming at, and a few other production expendables. Ultimately, we know what are the most important elements of the film and we would try to keep as much funding as possible in those departments.

We understand not everyone has money to donate, here are other ways you can get involved!

  • Help us make some noise with this film! Sharing on social media and spreading the word about this film is just as important as a donation.
  • Use Indiegogo to help us share and promote this campaign so we can make this film to the best of its ability!

Additional information

  1. If you wish to make a donation without wanting a perk, you may simply hit the "Back it" button on top of the page with the amount of your choosing.
  2. Have any questions about the film/ campaign we didn't answer? Contact us directly - happyfoxproductions@yahoo.com

story:
Help bring the Camifly printed pull over Hoodie to YOU!!!

Being a ONE women team, I need YOUR BACKING to ship out the final product of the Camifly Printed Hoodie. This is a spring inspired print for women to wear every day. The Hoodie is ready to reach lovers fingers. Help me bring the hoodies to YOU! Sizes run average based for the average women body size (xs - xxl)! Together, we can Spring a little beauty back into this Fall!

CHECK OUT WWW.CAMIFLYWEAR.COM TO SEE WHAT HAS BEEN STARTED!

My name is Brittany Bashaw and I am the creator of Camifly. I am a full time student on my last year of college and looking forward to graduating with a Bachelors in Business Administration concentrated in business management and minor in accounting. I married my high-school sweetheart and we have two beautiful children ages 4 and 1.

So, this mom tries to do it all but CANNOT DO THIS WITHOUT YOU!

DEAD LEAVES ARE FOR HUNTING!

Camifly is bringing something new and different that is full of life and color. Typically, the everyday camo women can wear offers only the color pink. However, the new spring inspired print was created from real trees found in nature with a women touch. This gives women a chance to wear the beauty found in Nature with remarkable colors! Instead of blending in, YOU WILL defiantly stand out in the New Cami Printed Hoodie!

It NOT Camo, Its CAMI for Her

Help support the the Camifly printed Hoodie! GET ONE NOW!

Camifly does not forget those who contributes and grows with Camifly, will include many benefits for YOU along the way! 

CHECK OUT WHAT HAS BEEN FINISHED!!!

 

TANK TOP IS READY FOR YOU TO WEAR NOW!!! 

NEXT DESIGN TO BE STARTED!!!

story:
THE FILM: 'SEMPRE':

My short film is called 'Sempre' -  it's an Italian word that's used as a musical direction meaning "always" or "throughout".

What would happen if one day you get struck by a lightning bolt, you wake up from your coma to find that the traumatic injury you sustained in one part of the brain has unlocked hidden talents in another part? Do you remain the same person, or does the new re-wiring of your brain alter you to a person you’ve never known before? 'Sempre' is a short film dramatizing a case of Acquired Savant Syndrome, in which a mild-mannered, middle-aged businessman transforms into an obsessive musical genius.



We follow the story of a bland, harmless, middle-aged Russell Gray who seems to have it all: a flourishing business, a loving wife, Karen and a talented daughter, Fiona. After sustaining brain damage that initially passes unnoticed, he develops a rare neurological disorder which enables his brain to unleash incredible musical abilities and relentless auditory hallucinations. As he refuses treatment, he slowly grows obsessive with his "gifts" and morphs into a person very different to who we met in the beginning of the film, alienating his family, losing his business, and ultimately himself.  It's a story about how fickle we human beings are and how the slightest re-wiring in our brains could alter the core of what makes us who we are so drastically.


What am I about, exactly?
Not a whole lot. I chose journalism as my major in undergraduate school partly because I had a thing or two for writing, but mostly because it was the major that offered its students the most electives. What could go wrong?  I studied news writing but also philosophy and history. I took up an astronomy module, a film analysis seminar, and in my senior year, I got graded on my singing. I could even spare a study abroad year in Japan that counted towards my credits. By the time I graduated, I was ready for what Egypt had in stock for its population of prospective journalists: turbulence, uncertainty, death tolls, a landscape constantly changing beyond recognition and a bottomless hat of stories about human beings trying to come to terms with it all. Having worked two years in news reporting for print and radio, I realized that there's got to be a better way to tell all these stories, a way that doesn't reduce their subjects to a number in a headline or a source at the tail of a quote. I just found myself gravitating towards film. An application season later, I got myself a scholarship to go study Digital Film and TV Production in the University of York.


Learning Filmmaking

I've spent the last few months on a roller coaster of a self-discovery experience. I started out as a film fan, and by now I have learned how to dismantle a £65,000 industry-standard camera, how to light a set and not kill myself or burn my hair in the process of doing it, how Alfred Hitchcock could have pulled his other-worldly works of genius off, how I can write my own film script, and down the line, direct it. Most of all, I've learnt the sheer capacity of hard labour that creating a film entails, the logistical mountains that stand in the way, the masses of people shooting a scene involves, and how absolutely rejuvenating it must feel to see the fruit of your work communicated to people you've never met, and in ideal world, move them.

The learning curve has been so steep it's a miracle I haven't broken my neck (yet). Now it's time to put it all to test. I've written my first short twenty-minute film as part of my course, and now is the time to turn the words on the page into pictures on the screen. In order to make this film, I need a crew (people who help me on set but don't appear on the screen), a cast (those who do appear on the screen), shooting locations and to be able to move the crew, cast, equipment and myself to these locations. Each single component of these requires money. Money I don't have much of, being an Egyptian student in the UK surviving off of a scholarship bursary and all. In order to graduate, I don't get to write a dissertation about film, I get to make one.

What We Need & What You Get

My university is providing about 15% of the funds I need for the film, I'm cutting down my own living costs to chip in with something. I do realize GBP 1500 might seem like a massive sum, but here's the breakdown of where the costs will go:

·  Equipment transportation: £ 200

·  Crew and Cast expenses: £ 500

·  Location expenses: £ 200

·  Catering: £ 300

·  Production design: £ 300

Why £ 1500?

I have been so lucky in that so many talented filmmaking enthusiasts have approached me and expressed their will to be part of my crew, totally free of charge. It’s a non-paid job, but I have to reimburse everybody's transportation and lodging expenses, as well as provide them with enough food to keep them going. I happen to have several crew members coming from different parts of the UK into York. In addition, because my casting requirements are quite particular (in addition to acting skills, I need from three of my actors to have had piano playing experience as well), I haven't been able to find local actors, and have had to reach out to ones in major (and, unfortunately, further) cities like London and Manchester.

If, by way of a miracle, we surpass our goal, we will use the additional finds to submit the film into different film festivals in and outside of the UK.

What you get in Return?

Donors make the film. It's as simple as that. With your help I would be able to create this film and use it as a launching pad to future projects. While I almost have the talent donors nailed, now I am in desperate need for the help of financial donors.

Your donations will be matched with varieties of rewards, from a digital copy of the film, to an "Associate Producer" credit, depending on the amount you decide to pledge.

The Impact

What I love about our story in 'Sempre' is that, in theory, it could happen to any of us - we all have brains; mysterious, powerful brains, which we know too little about.

It's my first ever filmmaking experience, but I certainly hope it won't be my last. I will do my best to make the best film I can, with the limited resources and short experience I have, and turn it into a launching pad to other projects I already have brewing in my head for when I go back to Egypt.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please share, share, share and share!

I've spent
the last few months on a roller coaster of a self-discovery experience. I
started out as a film fan, and by now I have learned how to dismantle a
£65,000 industry-standard camera, how to light a set and not kill myself
or burn my hair in the process of doing it, how Alfred Hitchcock could have
pulled his other-worldly works of genius off, how I can write my own film
script, and down the line, direct it. Most of all, I've learnt the sheer
capacity of hard labour that creating a film entails, the logistical mountains
that stand in the way, the masses of people shooting a scene involves, and how
absolutely rejuvenating it must feel to see the fruit of your work communicated
to people you've never met, and in ideal world, move them. 
The learning
curve has been so steep it's a miracle I haven't broken my neck (yet). Now it's
time to put it all to test. I've written my first short twenty-minute film as
part of my course, and now is the time to turn the words on the page into
pictures on the screen. In order to make this film, I need a crew (people who
help me on set but don't appear on the screen), a cast (those who do appear on
the screen), shooting locations and to be able to move the crew, cast,
equipment and myself to these locations. Each single component of these
requires money. Money I don't have much of, being an Egyptian student in the UK
surviving off of a scholarship bursary and all. In order to graduate, I don't
get to write a dissertation about film, I get to make one. 
What We Need & What You Get
My university is providing about 15%
of the funds I need for the film, I'm cutting down my own living costs to chip
in with something. I do realize GBP 1500 might seem like a massive sum, but
here's the breakdown of where the costs will go:

·  Equipment
transportation: £ 200
·  Crew and Cast
expenses: £ 500
·  Location
expenses: £ 200
·  Catering: £ 300
·  Production
design: £ 300
Why £ 1500?
I have been so lucky in that so many
talented filmmaking enthusiasts have approached me and expressed their will to
be part of my crew, totally free of charge. It’s a non-paid job, but I have to
reimburse everybody's transportation and lodging expenses, as well as provide
them with enough food to keep them going. I happen to have several crew members
coming from different parts of the UK into York. In addition, because my
casting requirements are quite particular (in addition to acting skills, I need
from three of my actors to have had piano playing experience as well), I
haven't been able to find local actors, and have had to reach out to ones in major
(and, unfortunately, further) cities like London and Manchester. 
If, by way
of a miracle, we surpass our goal, we will use the additional finds to submit
the film into different film festivals in and outside of the UK. 
What you get in Return?
Donors make the film. It's as simple
as that. With your help I would be able to create this film and use it as a
launching pad to future projects. While I almost have the talent donors nailed, now
I am in desperate need for the help of financial donors. 
Your
donations will be matched with varieties of rewards, from a digital copy of the
film, to an "Associate Producer" credit, depending on the amount you
decide to pledge. 
The Impact
What I love about our story in
'Sempre' is that, in theory, it could happen to any of us - we all have brains;
mysterious, powerful brains, which we know too little about.
It's my
first ever filmmaking experience, but I certainly hope it won't be my last. I
will do my best to make the best film I can, with the limited resources and
short experience I have, and turn it into a launching pad to other projects I
already have brewing in my head for when I go back to Egypt. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute,
but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Please
share, share, share and share!

story:
Cop brutality is an epidemic that consistently shows the nations lack of change since slavery. Sandra Bland is of the many Americans who has experienced unnecessary violence and violations from law enforcement due to her heritage. On June 10th, 2015 Bland was assaulted and arrested by officer Brian Encinia for allegedly failing to signal . Three days later she was found hanged in a Waller County jail cell. 

Sandra Bland and her sisters babysat my brothers and I growing up in the suburbs of Chicago. Our parents were very close, and I grew up thinking of her as a cousin. I found myself lost after her death - I wouldn't wish the pain that comes from a tragedy like this on anyone. Unable to make sense of the situation, I found that the only way I could find some peace was through song. "Sandy's Freestyle" was written a few days after. The emotional pain in the song reflects how we wish we could have been there with her in her time of need. 

After endless months without answers I, Martise Omega, would like to complete the song with a corresponding short film - my attempt to ease the suffering from her family and those that knew her.

This short film will follow the day and the life of Sandra Bland before her arrest. We wish to show the true essence of the loving being she was, as her light has been completely dimmed in the media. Her death is now the only thing she is known for, and I want to show that she is so much more than a casualty.  

We are raising $5000 for the project to shoot June 11th. Your donations will help fly the crew to Chicago so that we can have her family be a part of the film. Our goal release date is July 13th - the one year anniversary of her death. 

Awareness is our goal. Waiting in silence is not an option and being a headline is not the life Sandra deserved. We only wish to bring justice and peace to Sandra Bland. Support anyway you can. Share the link, and don't forget to include #SandysFreestyle in your posts. 

If you would like to join the #SandysFreestyle movement or be a part of the short film, please email me at tise6love@gmail.com



Martise Omega:

Martise Omega's powerhouse voice is the result of a strong church upbringing. At the tender age of 4, her vocals catapulted her as a soloist in the adult choir  -bringing responsibility and courage to the forefront - all with the guidance of the Lord. An observant and natural healer, she would often hide in her room, writing poems based on her realizations of the world around her. In her senior year of high school, she uncovered the gift of songwriting. After studying theatre in Dekalb, IL she moved to Los Angeles, CA  to continue developing and shaping her future in the arts. A multifaceted woman - Martise hit the ground running - starting multiple projects aimed at reviving the arts, healing the spirit, and rebuilding the community of L.A.

story:
My name is Lee A Brian, and this is my first movie. I wrote "Serious Applicants Only" back in 2008 and had it copyrighted. Earlier 2016, I published it on Amazon as a novella. Once we complete filming, we will upload it to streaming sites and Netflix will be first. The money we raise from sales will go straight toward funding the next project. I am keeping my overhead low, so all I can focus on paying my talent. Vit Ultra Nex runs on Linux and Open Source tools, so really the only thing I need to buy will be my equipment.

The other reason I am starting this campaign, is so our fans can get swag and everyone can see how much money we are earning.

Your donations will go toward paying the child actors in the teaser trailer first, then buying the camera. We are working on scheduling other scenes, while we campaign. Thank you for your interest!

story:
Greater Danbury, CT Filmmakers To Produce Homegrown Horror Film!

Hello, my name is Angel Rosa and I am the writer, producer, and director of the feature horror-suspense anthology film, Contrived. I was born and raised in...

Hold on. Wait. Before I go on about myself, how about a little bit about the premise of our movie. Contrived  is an anthology film, which of course means that it's made up of several stories, each produced separately as 'modules' that will eventually come together, all interwoven around a central story. They will be linked in various ways, mostly subtle, but all tied into the grand premise. 

Tobias Werrick is a veteran filmmaker who becomes disillusioned and disgusted with the state of modern filmmaking. Tobias is an eccentric sort, for sure, but we all know he's spot-on in his accusations of Hollywood's lack of original thinking of late.

Tobias attends the annual Cardinal Hollow Horror Fest where he meets Abigail Fernand, an acclaimed young writer and director who is to be honored at the night's event. He approaches Abigail, and through a mix of wit and flirtation, and a bit of charming quirkiness, laments to Abigail on the sorry state of modern mainstream films. "The seemingly endless remakes, the bland regurgitation of old plot-lines and premises, and the creative impotence currently plaguing Hollywood."  

Tobias smiles as he tells her how he will whisk her away, to have her as a captive audience of one, as he shares with her ideas for fresh and "original" concepts that he believes would make good cinema.  These are the tales we will show in the film. 

Abigail is intrigued at first, then finds cause to grow increasingly more concerned, which soon escalates to full blown terror. Are these stories purely fiction from the mind of a brilliant, if admittedly bizarre individual? Or are they the fictional by-products of terrifying real life deeds?  

Abigail will attempt to sort out the truth, as her very life may depend on it. And I wouldn't be surprised if she ends up with a story of her own to share. 

Which brings me back to that headline: 

Greater Danbury, CT Filmmakers To Produce Homegrown Horror Film

As I was saying, my name is Angel Rosa and I'm a native of Western Connecticut, having been born and raised in the great 'Hat City' of Danbury; which runs smack-dab against the border with New York State. That gives us Hat City citizens a unique sensibility, mixing New England charm with a kind of New York wit and hipness. We tend to be introspective and witty, neighborly and gritty all at once. Artistically this produces a distinct creative style unique to the Greater Danbury region.  You can hear it in our music, see it in our art, and feel it in our poetry and storytelling. 

Danbury has a rich history of movers and shakers from a variety of disciplines, themselves all products of that one-of-a-kind Hat City culture. From people like Charles Ives, son of a former marching band leader, who went on to become a world renowned composer, to folks like Jerry Nadeau, son of a former Danbury Race Arena modified car racer, who went from racing go-karts all the way to NASCAR.    

Then there's the story of me, Angel Rosa, a single father who still finds himself occasionally going to the Coinstar, or to the bottle redemption area at Stop & Shop for gas money to get back and forth to work everyday. (You want to talk about humility?) Nevertheless, I am an incredibly proud parent, which in itself makes me profoundly rich in so many ways that money cannot. I'm the son of a U.S. Navy veteran, former police officer, and musician father currently retired from Yankee Gas/Connecticut Light & Power after three decades of employment. I am also the son of an equally hard-working mother currently retired  from Pitney Bowes after almost two decades of employment. 

My legacy, and that of so many others on this team, has yet to be written. But YOU can be a part of those legacies, by helping us in any way you can to make this film a reality. 

You can also be a part of adding to the rich cinematic history of Greater Danbury, a place where legendary filmmakers have come to make movies. People like Alfred Hitchcock, Paul Newman, Frank Oz, Norman Jewison, Bob Balaban, Rebecca Miller, Wes Craven, and so many others. 

Here's What We Need, and What You'll Get

We need to reach an absolute minimum goal of $10,000 to complete, The Tutor, the first module of the feature, with an ideal goal of $50,000 overall to get all of the modules produced and complete this entire film.  We will use every penny of the funds for pre-production planning, production, and post-production. Your contributions will go toward paying our lead actors, providing a modest stipend to crew, hiring production specialists like cinematographers, sound engineers, gaffers, special effects makeup artists, visual effects artists (all practical effects, by the way---NO CGI), logistics costs, production design, editing, color correction, and of course, catering to feed the cast and crew; probably the most important part! 

We have some amazing perks to offer our contributors; from having your name listed in the "Special Thanks" section of the closing credits, to earning yourself a SMOKING HOT Hat City Pictures t-shirts; from Contrived mini-posters, to dinner with the cast and crew. There are even spots available for 'Executive Producers', where'll you'll get to visit the set of the film, get full Executive Producer credit, and hang out with us while we make movie magic, and more!!!!

It All Depends On YOU!

The film promises to be a unique, fascinating, and entertaining examination of the current state of Hollywood. It's intended as a respectful nod to the great Hollywood of old, and a not-so-subtle indictment of the lack of originality currently evident in mainstream American cinema. 

With your financial support, we can put out something original and fresh. Something thought-provoking, genuinely unnerving, and ultimately loads of fun. 

If I may be allowed to do some moderate self back-patting, I'm very proud of my accomplishments as a published writer and filmmaker whose films have toured film festivals throughout Connecticut and New York. And I'm especially proud of my entire team, collectively boasting 30 years of Award Winning experience working on stage, television, and film. 

Making movies, especially feature length movies, and especially feature length movies with original, creative content is NOT easy. And it's certainly NOT cheap. Frankly, and I will just be blunt here: without you, we're finished before we can even begin. This is a team building exercise, and very much one rooted in community support. Without you having our backs, well, it's going to make it next to impossible to get it done. We need your support, your solidarity, your commitment, your loyalty, and your love!

So why the heck should you trust me?

Great question. Well, for starters, because I'm a parent. But not just a parent, I'm a single parent. In fact, I'm a single dad to an amazing young lady, who's 12 going on 21. She's not disrespectful, but she certainly isn't a pushover either. And she's been that way her entire life. I've raised my daughter alone since she was six, and I will tell you all, there are none more tender and understanding when it's appropriate to be, or more brutally honest when it's appropriate to be. (Even sometimes when it's maybe not so appropriate to be.) 

Bottom line: She'd never let me get away with anything other than 100% commitment. And she never allows me to look down on myself. Trust me, I'm human, and every single one of us, especially us artists, flirt with self-consciousness from time to time, and we can often be our very own worst critics. With this little one in my life, there's no time for any of that bull. She picks me up the moment I start slipping. And, in reality, I just know better now. It's not all or nothing, it's "Everything; absolutely and uncompromisingly so!"

This film is just as much for the audience, as it is for her, and for all the families of every single member of our team, which in itself is a creative family. I would be most honored if you could be a part of that family.

I ask you with the greatest humility: Please help us spread the word from sidewalk to rooftop. Please, help us and join Team Contrived!!!

With the warmest regards, 

Angel Rosa 
Writer, Producer, Director, 
Contrived
