story:
What are MOGU sleeves and how to use them?

MOGU sleeves are very long pieces of colorful, soft and light fabric sewn to form sleeves which tie together to be worn. They are really simple to use and make the play free and open. When you put them on, the whole new world opens up for you to explore! They simply urge the motion, make you spin, make you run, and they just fly behind you. They make you reach further and enable to touch and connect beyond the expected.
 

MOGU sleeves can become the wings of a dragon or a dress of a princess, the magic rays of a powerful wizard or a fearsome typhoon. It all depends on you and your imagination. There are no instructions or guidelines – so be prepared to be surprised!

They are suitable both for children and for adults. Get silly with your kids. Set yourself free!

MOGU sleeves are easy to pack and carry with you.

Material used is high quality, soft, lite and very pleasant to the sense of touch.

 

 

Where the inspiration came from?

Inspiration for MOGU sleeves comes from a form of dance – the traditional Chinese dancing with long-sleeves. You might have seen it in the “House of Flying Daggers” movie.
 

The creator of MOGU sleeves has personally been practicing the 5 Rhythms dance for years:

“5 Rhythms dance has benefited me in many different ways. It liberated me. It helped me find my freedom both in movement and in spirit and made me realize how these two are connected. I started out as someone who was more comfortable staying at the corner of the dance hall. I hardly moved my arms while dancing. But now, I find the Lyrical rhythm, the one of 5 with the emphasis on arms, joy and ease of being, closest to my true nature. When my movements are wide and when I take A LOT of space, it feels great! I feel great – and that amazing feeling transfers further to all other aspects of life, and I am truly grateful for it. MOGU sleeves are the manifestation of this energy, this joy of life!”

 

 

Why are they valuable?

MOGU sleeves set you free! This simple, yet amazing plaything inspires movement. It creates a situation which is different than usual, and the sense of wonder is awakened. The exploration starts. You can’t be sure what you will find. You need to move and find out. Move your arms, move your feet, move closer to your play-mate, move away, spin, run, jump, wave, stop, chase, ketch, pull, rest, breathe, get tangled, untangle, move gracefully, move fast or move slow, even slower... This exploration of movement ignites the imaginative play. Move slow as a snail with the sleeve being a slimy trail, or move strongly like a wind! Remember – how does a king move in his robe? A gymnast with a ribbon? A wave in the ocean? A fish with exotic colorful fins? A bird? A lizard?

Physical activity is very important for healthy development of children and maintaining the health of adults. But if the physical activity is also fun, it can be elevated into something more. It can move the entire being by awaking the sense of wonder, creativity, imagination, emotions, interactions, the freedom itself.

 

 

Why crowdfunding

Creating toys and playthings is a passion that people involved in MOGU sleeves share and would love to keep sharing it with others! Croudfunding is a great way to reach a greater audience, connect with people, get feedback, and develop new toys through play. The more people play the better.

Reaching the goal would enable us to produce a series of MOGU sleeves for new playmates out there and help the rest of MOGU toys become more than an idea, but a real playmate on a real playground. That means being able to buy materials, hire 2 people to help us sew, organize marketing and start selling!

Thank you very much for your attention! We greatly appreciate any kind of support you can provide – through donations to our campaign or helping spread the word about this project.

 

Meet the team

Aleksandra Mikan - Product designer - the creative force behind MOGU toys.

Duška Matović Milošević - Economist and marketing strategist

Lela Đerković - mother of 4 - main advisor

Ilija and Nada Soldat - sowing artists

 

Contributors

Miloš Jovanović - photography

Neda Šorak - Project Advisor from Nova Iskra

Ana Ćakić - copywrite

Jelina Janković - painting on sleeves

 

Credits

Music for the video: Peacoat by Blue Dot Sessions

Font used for sleeves personalization: Mightype Script

 

Rewards

For all rewards you will be able to choose from 5 available colors, and 3 sleeve lengths. Longest sleeves are 2m long (size L) and are suitable for parents as well as for kids above 6 years old. Middle size is 1.6m (size M) and suits kids from 3 to 6 yeas old. The smallest sleeves are 1.2m (size S). MOGU sleeves are not recommended for children under the age of 3 - if you use them you need to be careful so kids do not trip over them, since they will drag on the ground. These recommendations are approximate. You can decide what is best for your kids based on their height. Consider that 40cm goes to tie them and the rest of the length will hang from the shoulder.

 

 

Personalized MOGU sleeves

If you would like a more personal touch, we will paint a letter of your choice on your MOGU sleeves - or it can be two different letters, one on each sleeve. For the letters we use the Mightype Script font, and they are hand painted by our dear friend Jelina.

 

Unique hand painted MOGU sleeves

Hand painted by lovely and talented Jelina Janković - one off a kind MOGU sleeves. An additional creative touch for those who want more. For a music lover to move with the rhythm of the wind. These are in size M - ready to be sent. Jelina is working on some more beautiful creations, so if you like these, keep your eyes open for additional perks during the campaign.

 

A BIG wave at you from the MOGU toys team!

Follow MOGU toys on facebook!

Thank you for your support! <3
story_txt:
What are MOGU sleeves and how to use them?MOGU sleeves are very long pieces of colorful, soft and light fabric sewn to form sleeves which tie together to be worn. They are really simple to use and make the play free and open. When you put them on, the whole new world opens up for you to explore! They simply urge the motion, make you spin, make you run, and they just fly behind you. They make you reach further and enable to touch and connect beyond the expected. 
MOGU sleeves can become the wings of a dragon or a dress of a princess, the magic rays of a powerful wizard or a fearsome typhoon. It all depends on you and your imagination. There are no instructions or guidelines – so be prepared to be surprised!
They are suitable both for children and for adults. Get silly with your kids. Set yourself free!
MOGU sleeves are easy to pack and carry with you.
Material used is high quality, soft, lite and very pleasant to the sense of touch.
 

 
Where the inspiration came from?Inspiration for MOGU sleeves comes from a form of dance – the traditional Chinese dancing with long-sleeves. You might have seen it in the “House of Flying Daggers” movie. 
The creator of MOGU sleeves has personally been practicing the 5 Rhythms dance for years:
“5 Rhythms dance has benefited me in many different ways. It liberated me. It helped me find my freedom both in movement and in spirit and made me realize how these two are connected. I started out as someone who was more comfortable staying at the corner of the dance hall. I hardly moved my arms while dancing. But now, I find the Lyrical rhythm, the one of 5 with the emphasis on arms, joy and ease of being, closest to my true nature. When my movements are wide and when I take A LOT of space, it feels great! I feel great – and that amazing feeling transfers further to all other aspects of life, and I am truly grateful for it. MOGU sleeves are the manifestation of this energy, this joy of life!”
 

 

Why are they valuable?
MOGU sleeves set you free! This simple, yet amazing plaything inspires movement. It creates a situation which is different than usual, and the sense of wonder is awakened. The exploration starts. You can’t be sure what you will find. You need to move and find out. Move your arms, move your feet, move closer to your play-mate, move away, spin, run, jump, wave, stop, chase, ketch, pull, rest, breathe, get tangled, untangle, move gracefully, move fast or move slow, even slower... This exploration of movement ignites the imaginative play. Move slow as a snail with the sleeve being a slimy trail, or move strongly like a wind! Remember – how does a king move in his robe? A gymnast with a ribbon? A wave in the ocean? A fish with exotic colorful fins? A bird? A lizard?
Physical activity is very important for healthy development of children and maintaining the health of adults. But if the physical activity is also fun, it can be elevated into something more. It can move the entire being by awaking the sense of wonder, creativity, imagination, emotions, interactions, the freedom itself.
 

 

Why crowdfunding
Creating toys and playthings is a passion that people involved in MOGU sleeves share and would love to keep sharing it with others! Croudfunding is a great way to reach a greater audience, connect with people, get feedback, and develop new toys through play. The more people play the better.
Reaching the goal would enable us to produce a series of MOGU sleeves for new playmates out there and help the rest of MOGU toys become more than an idea, but a real playmate on a real playground. That means being able to buy materials, hire 2 people to help us sew, organize marketing and start selling!
Thank you very much for your attention! We greatly appreciate any kind of support you can provide – through donations to our campaign or helping spread the word about this project.
 
Meet the team
Aleksandra Mikan - Product designer - the creative force behind MOGU toys.
Duška Matović Milošević - Economist and marketing strategist
Lela Đerković - mother of 4 - main advisor
Ilija and Nada Soldat - sowing artists
 
Contributors
Miloš Jovanović - photography
Neda Šorak - Project Advisor from Nova Iskra
Ana Ćakić - copywrite
Jelina Janković - painting on sleeves
 
Credits
Music for the video: Peacoat by Blue Dot Sessions
Font used for sleeves personalization: Mightype Script
 
Rewards
For all rewards you will be able to choose from 5 available colors, and 3 sleeve lengths. Longest sleeves are 2m long (size L) and are suitable for parents as well as for kids above 6 years old. Middle size is 1.6m (size M) and suits kids from 3 to 6 yeas old. The smallest sleeves are 1.2m (size S). MOGU sleeves are not recommended for children under the age of 3 - if you use them you need to be careful so kids do not trip over them, since they will drag on the ground. These recommendations are approximate. You can decide what is best for your kids based on their height. Consider that 40cm goes to tie them and the rest of the length will hang from the shoulder.
 

 
Personalized MOGU sleeves
If you would like a more personal touch, we will paint a letter of your choice on your MOGU sleeves - or it can be two different letters, one on each sleeve. For the letters we use the Mightype Script font, and they are hand painted by our dear friend Jelina.


 
Unique hand painted MOGU sleeves
Hand painted by lovely and talented Jelina Janković - one off a kind MOGU sleeves. An additional creative touch for those who want more. For a music lover to move with the rhythm of the wind. These are in size M - ready to be sent. Jelina is working on some more beautiful creations, so if you like these, keep your eyes open for additional perks during the campaign.

 
A BIG wave at you from the MOGU toys team!
Follow MOGU toys on facebook!
Thank you for your support! <3

story:
My short film project, "Pale Blue Eye" is inspired by "Tell-Tale Heart" by Edgar Allan Poe. My experience with this story began at St. Elizabeth Elementary School in Bronzeville on the south side of Chicago three decades ago when a theatre company performed a stage play of the story for the students. I am an alumnus and former 5th Grade teacher at St. Elizabeth School, so my history with this educational institution runs deep. Unfortunately, today the doors of the school are closed, but the church still stands as a beacon light of hope in the Bronzeville community. My journey as a storyteller and filmmaker began at St. "E." Although the school wasn't operating, I felt that somehow it wasn't done with me yet. 

As I began the search for one of the critical locations for “Pale Blue Eye,” St. Elizabeth immediately came to mind.  I called the church office and set a meeting with the board of trustees. We discussed my plans for the film and their plans to possibly reopen in the future. Later, they unanimously voted for us to shoot our film in the basement of the former church building. The old church was where I experienced "Tell-Tale Heart" for the first time. So, it felt surreal to return to my old stomping ground with the cast and crew of my new movie inspired by "Tell-Tale Heart." The church's basement turned out to be the perfect location. It was a massive unfinished space and had the eerie look we needed to help compellingly tell the story. 

So, what is this movie about? I can better answer that question by explaining what my movie is not about. “Pale Blue Eye” is not a regurgitation of “Tell-Tale Heart.” Many filmmakers have taken the literal approach when adapting this narrative. However, I wanted to do something different. My mission became retelling the story in a familiar but different way while adding a twist of diversity.

The logline for my film is as follows: "Pale Blue Eye" by Keith A. Nixon is the story of a black woman named Norma Redmond, who is a schizophrenic surgical assistant for a crooked doctor who becomes haunted by the sound of her employer’s heartbeat after she murders him.

During our previous campaign for “Pale Blue Eye,” we raised over 3,000 dollars in 13 days to shoot our movie. We began principal photography on July 17th, 2017 at 5 AM and we wrapped production on July 21st, 2017 at 11:57 PM. This amounted to an intense five-day shooting schedule. The cosmetic conditions of the space made it a tough shoot, (lots of dust, limited electrical power, no working restrooms on site). We worked well as a team under pressure and found solutions to the problems that challenged us.  The result of our sacrifice and hard work was capturing beautiful footage that made it all worth the extra effort.

Now that production is complete we are ready to move the film forward into the Post-Production process. Our post-production process is broken down into two parts: Assembly and Finishing.

During the assembly phase, our editors work on building the film, piecing together all the shots, scenes, sequences, and sound bites until the picture is locked and ready for the second step, finishing.

When we enter the finishing phase, we will deliver the editor's assembly of the film to Periscope Post & Sound, one of the leading post-production houses in Chicago, IL. They have completed post-production on feature films, documentaries, commercials, and network television shows. The experts at Periscope will help take "Pale Blue Eye" to the next level by refining the assembly edits, professional color grading, and the final mix of sound & music. Having the Periscope advantage will give our film the professional finish it deserves. Below is a copy of a quote and schedule we received from Periscope Post & Sound with the next steps to complete for post-production:

Polish edit w/ in-house editor 3 days    
For 5.1 mix (full M&E pass) + Full color, based on 8-hour days
Assembly + spot                    2 days          
Sound design                        3 days      
Dia edit                                  2 days           
Foley record                          3 days         
Foley edit                              2 days              
BGs + Spot FX                      2 days           
Unsupervised mix                 2 days         
Client Review                        2 days        
Grade + Conform                  2 days        
Review                                  .5 day
Output                                   .5 day  
TOTAL: $6250

After we complete the finishing process at Periscope Post & Sound, our film will be ready to enter the film festival circuit.  Once the movie is complete, we will also have a private screening of the film at St. Elizabeth to help raise awareness of the possible reopening of the school in Bronzeville. 

Please support our campaign to raise funds for post-production. You can help us by purchasing an awesome perk from our indiegogo campaign like a prop used in the film or a customized T-shirt with the original storyboard artwork on the front, and the name of the movie and a list of cast & crew on the back. If you’re not interested in a perk but still want to support our film, you can also donate any dollar amount you like to help us reach our goal. I am passionate about our campaign, and I’m even more excited to see “Pale Blue Eye” come to a screen near you. Thanks for your interest in supporting our film and for helping us cross the post-production finish line. Visit our website at www.paleblueeyefilm.com for more updates about the film and dates for future screenings. 

See you at the movies!

Yours truly,
Keith A. Nixon,
Writer/Director/Producer

story:
Synopsis

Dave Heeley has decided that he wants to follow in the footsteps of renowned explorer and adventurer Sir Ranulph Fiennes and complete one of the toughest marathons in the world, the “Sevens” -  seven marathons on seven continents in seven days. The only problem is that Dave is completely blind.

Through the use of flashbacks, 7 DAYS will tell the incredible story of how after being diagnosed at the age of ten with a condition that would eventually rob him of his sight, Dave would go on to become an inspiration to thousands all around the world.

As filmmakers, we are drawn to true stories that are both inspiring and incredible. Not only is Dave’s story one of the most amazing stories of overcoming adversity that we have come across, he also happens to be from the Midlands and as a Midland based filmmakers ourselves, it’s great to be making a film about a local hero!

However, we do believe that Dave shouldn't be just a local hero, but one that is better known around the world and it's our aim to make that happen. We truly believe that this film will have the power to inspire others who are facing disadvantages in life to pursue their dreams and never give up.

The film is already gathering a lot of interest, and on our last shoot (in January), we had  BBC Midlands visiting our set! Check out their piece on the film below!

 

We have already managed to secure enough funding to push the film through development and into production - but to enable us to create the film that we envisage, we still need to raise more money in order to cover the costs of recreating certain locations, hiring costumes and props, and of course, paying our hard working crew and cast.

It's a cliche, but every penny really will help us to make this film. Be a part of our journey as we make this film a reality!

 

 

The word is already getting out!

“The West Bromwich Albion Football club and the Albion Foundation is absolutely delighted that a film is being made about Dave”.

Rob Lake -  Albion Foundation

 

 

Who are we?

Pixel Revolution Films is a Midland based film production company that aims to make films that inspire. Our work in the past has garnered several awards and nominations and we pride ourselves on our distinct visual style.

We are a team of creatives passionate about telling stories. Heading the team on 7 DAYS are:

 

OUR CAST:

Working in partnership with

While making this film, we will also be working with  South & City College Birmingham, the largest college in Birmingham, allowing their film and media students to gain valuable work experience on a real set, working to real deadlines.

Above: Make-up students from South & City College Birmingham, on the set of 7 DAYS with Harry Potter actor Oliver Phelps. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise £7,000 to complete the filming and to ensure the high quality of production is ensured all the way through to the “post-production” stage, that is the process of editing, sound-mixing and music scoring/licensing.

The money will also go to funding:

Props & Costumes.  As several scenes take place during Dave’s childhood and young adulthood, we will need to hire specialised period props and costumes. Although most of our props and costumes are being very kindly donated to us from the Birmingham Rep Theatre, there are several specialised pieces of costumes we will need to hire or buy, such as running outfits.

Stock footage. We intend to use stock footage of the real Dave Heeley and mix it in with the dramatic reconstructions that we film, to create a sense of authenticity to those scenes. ITV who own the copyright to the news footage of Dave running the Sevens has quoted us £450 for 30 seconds of footage.

Music Score. We intend to work with a composer to create a score that will fit perfectly to our film.

Film festival entry fees. We want to get Dave’s story out there, we want the film to get attention and one of the best ways to do this is to get selected for film festivals around the world.

In return for your support check out the cool perks we have listed opposite.

If you're purchasing a perk as gift for someone else, please be sure to let us know the name  you wish to have on the personalised items.

The Impact

In his book, FROM LIGHT TO DARK, Dave mentions a moment just after completing the “Sevens”, when he overheard a blind boy in the crowd saying to his friend, “If he can do this, what can I do?” This sums up exactly the reason we want to make this film.

Dave’s story is incredibly inspiring and with your help, our film can take Dave’s story to an even wider audience. No other medium has the emotional power of film to inspire and make a difference.

You'll also be helping a new generation of film-makers. As mentioned above, we will be working in partnership with Birmingham South and City College to ensure their film students get the valuable experience they need when starting out in this competitive industry. 

Risks & Challenges

Of course, every film is a challenge, especially one that is set in seven different countries and includes scenes set in the 1960s and 1970s. But challenges are something we thrive on as a team.

Our most recent feature film, All That Remains was filmed in Birmingham and set in 1940’s Japan. By employing green-screen technology and CGI we were able to convince a Japanese audience that it was filmed on location in Japan.

As George Lucas once said, the secret to film is that it’s an illusion and a quick look at our previous work will show you that we’ve become pretty adept at the art of illusion.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

                     

If you cannot afford to make a financial contribution, don’t worry there are still plenty of ways you can help. Tell your friends. family and work colleagues about our film and our campaign here on Indiegogo.

Be sure to use Indiegogo’s share tools to get the word out on your social media sites, the more people know about our campaign the more chance we have of achieving our goal.

story:
Who am I? 

I am Tony Pacheco, I am a filmmaker first and a dancer second. I found my passion for filmmaking through my shuffling simply by recording myself dancing in my spare time. From there It has lead me to pursue a career in the film industry fresh out of college.

 

About this film 

This documentary started out as a project assigned to me in my time in college that I took on a very large interest to. Out of the 6 years that I have been shuffling its almost that I am putting my own story as well as many more peoples stories into this film. I hope that this will inspire those that have no idea what shuffling is.     

 

Possible risks 

-This film is being independently produced and edited by me, and the most concrete date that I can say that the final product will be out is of some point in 2018. 

-all tshirts, Hoodies and heads of lettuce will be shipped out by me personally.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt: Short Summary Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:  Introduce yourself and your background. Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you. Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.  Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:  Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.  Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited! Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:  Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world. Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one). Make it real for people and build trust.    Risks & Challenges  People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.  Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. Describe your plan for solving these challenges.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who We Are

We are a small yet strong female led indie production company that focuses largely on the inner most workings of the human mind. Created and founded by a filmmaker Kasey Rae and actress Sancha Spiller, we as production company are able to understand both sides to a story to create a very dynamic approach. 

Our director Kasey Rae recently gained the rights through the dollar baby project run by Stephen King, to create a non - commercial adaptation of his short story; 'All That You Love Will Be Carried Away.'

What The Film Means To Us

Having felt the need for hope so strongly before, we want to bring people in a similar situation our of their isolation. A human's ability to drag themselves out of their darkest and strongest thoughts has always fascinated us. This film allows us to bring awareness to such a topic, and to put a reminder out there that you don't have to suffer for your art or lose an ear Van Gough style in order to create truthfully or successfully. Something that Alfie Zimmer certainly needs to be reminded of and we feel a lot of other people in the film industry need to be as well. 

This film allows the audience to dissect & explore this universal element locked away in most of our brains, and expose it. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're hiring a very talented crew to work with us on making this film. Rather than contributing to the exploitation of workers that this industry already faces, we want to pay them all a fair wage. Parts of our budget will also we going towards film festival entry fees so that our film can reach as wide an audience as possible. The remaining portion of our budget will be going to towards location, food and travel costs. 

A variety of perks will be available to those who help donate and make this film a reality. Everything from social media shoutouts, to stickers, songs from the cast and much more. 

If we are unable to hit our complete goal, we will be re-budgeting our funds and using the money we have received to still try and make this film a reality. Our main priority will always be assured that our crew and cast are paid fairly above all else. 

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

We truly feel this project is valuable not only to you as a contributor but to the world as it deals with topics that despite gaining awareness we still don't talk about enough. Suicide and mental health are at the forefront of this story and they're something that we as a team could relate to and that most people can. If not through personal experience then through that of someone you know. That's why it's important to tell stories about those subjects in a truthful and un glamorized way, a "raw" way and that's what we hope to do with this film. Also, the underlining sentiment of feeling trapped by day to day life and knowing that you have a bigger dream to achieve but not knowing how to go about that is something again that we feel like audiences can connect with, we want to give them an ally in Alfie. 

If anyone is fit to tell this story it's Kasey Rae, our director, and screenplay writer, who has had various pieces of her work published in numerous different outlets, most of which cover the human psyche in the film in some way. 

Other Ways You Can Help

As well as contributing to our campaign it would mean the world to us if you could spread the word, and tell those you know about the film. As an Indie newly established production company every penny counts, and the more of our budget we achieve the higher quality in which we can tell this story. You can share the page via the Indiegogo share tools, and follow the film on all of our social media platforms. 

The film and story we've created is a personal one. Life often reflects art and due to some of our production teams experiences, recently it has become obvious how much this story needs to be told.

story:
– Who We Are

We are a group of filmmakers from Baton Rouge, New Orleans, and Baltimore coming together to create "Jane." We believe the best way to make a film, especially this one, is with viewpoints and experiences that will help us make it thoughtfully, honestly, and authentically. So we are proud to tell this story with an incredibly diverse and talented crew helmed by these principle positions.

Director, Executive Producer – Abe Felix

Abe Felix is an award-winning director and cinematographer from Baton Rouge. Upon obtaining his bachelor’s degree in Mass Communications while minoring in Film and Media Arts from LSU, he quickly began working toward a fruitful career as a filmmaker. His background in writing and editing for print and television birthed his passion for visual storytelling. His credits range from second unit directing SYTYCD star Fikshun Stegall on a narrative feature All Styles in 2017 to directing documentaries for BREC, and Baton Rouge Area Foundation to countless television and web commercials for brands like ExxonMobil, BASF, BREC, Wellness, and Miss USA. To him filmmaking is a platform for saying things that truly matter, and he carries this responsibility into his craft. 

Producer/Production Coordinator – Deirdre Peterson

A California native that fell in love with Louisiana, and then a boy from New Orleans. She has lived in Louisiana on and off since 2002 and has over 10 years of film, video and live event production experience. Credits include American Heist, Final Girls and Lemonade by Beyonce. When she is not working on a production, she is looking for something new to watch, waiting anxiously for football season or traveling.

Producer/Locations Manager – Aquiles Montalvo 



Born and raised in New Orleans, Aquiles graduated with a BA in Film Production from UNO. He has since worked on countless feature films, television shows, music videos and commercials as a Locations Manager. He has always wanted to work in the film industry, in his home state. Notable credits include work on 21 Jump Street, Pitch Perfect 2, Underground, and Queen Sugar.

Director of Photography – Shannon Palmer


Shannon Palmer is a cinematographer and camera operator who began her focus on cinematography while studying at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, where she graduated with a BFA in Film. Shannon uses her unique vision to tell powerful stories in a visually-striking way. She is continually inspired by the human condition, and strives to subtly create a spark of intimacy between her subjects and the audience. She enjoys working on a wide variety of projects, including narratives, commercials, music videos, branded content, fashion films and documentaries. Shannon has DP'd and operated for many brands including Johns Hopkins, Under Armour, Planned Parenthood, Volkswagen, Visit Baltimore, Saint Agnes Hospital, Erickson Living, Fivex3 Training and more. She currently calls Baltimore home but can be found frequently traveling for work.

And this is just the start. Keep an eye for how this crew and cast continues to grow over the next few months!
 

– Why

"Jane" is the result of my good friend Cat (the lead actor) opening up to me about the identity struggles she faced as a young Vietnamese and Caucasian mixed female growing up in the American South and how it shaped her into the person she is today. As we spoke more and more, it became clear the best way to get her message of empowerment and overcoming the limitations society places upon us was to create a story that did just that. So in November 2016, we began co-writing a narrative short that I'll direct and Cat will star in as she pursues acting as a career choice. They say write what you know, and as two minorities in the south, we know what it means to be judged and mistreated based on outward appearance. We want to work to change that norm.

Often in society, identity is cultivated by our parents, caretakers, friends and influencers at a young age and then further cemented by biases and stereotypes of the public based on one’s appearance. But an increasing number of people worldwide are not afforded this right. I, the director, am and identify as African American with all the history and struggle that comes with it. My identity as a black man is set. It is a safe platform where I fit in with people who look like me, and extend myself from with people who do not. And for those of us in easily categorizable ethnicities, this is true. And until I began this project, I never knew what a privilege this was.

Imagine being a young person and growing up differently than everyone else, not fitting in with extended family, prospective friends, classmates all because of the way you look. Imagine trying to craft an identity around that and grow. This void of identity often creates a lack of self-worth, isolation, depression, and myriad other negative world-views and philosophies that in truth harm not only the individual but society as a whole. That is what “Jane” as a film seeks to shine light on. It can’t solve this problem on its own, but it can start a conversation that will put us on a path to greater empathy for multiracial people and society in general.

We are thoroughly excited to create this film, this collaboration of minority writers, with an incredibly hard-working and diverse team of filmmakers across age, gender, experience, and of course, ethnicity. The cross-pollination of viewpoints, world-views, and life experience is the most valuable thing this film has to offer and we believe there is no other way to make this film.

– Abe

The Look We're Going For

With Director of Photography Shannon Palmer on board, we will be working to achieve visuals similar to what Khalid Mohtaseb executed in a short film called "Bloom." You can find that film here: https://vimeo.com/128259653

Simple, natural, beautiful and full of emotional depth and meaning.

SUPPORT

We need you! The funds we're raising here take this project from pre-production all the way to the festival circuit and that doesn't happen without you joining us to make this happen. 11k may sound like a lot depending on where you're standing. But when we start to pay for these things listed, it all adds up fast:

  • Location Fees
  • Insurance
  • Equipment (like Camera, Lighting, and Sound)
  • Special Effects
  • Props and Wardrobe
  • Food and Water
  • Cast and Crew
  • Wrap Party
  • Post-Production (Editing, Audio, Original Music)
  • Film Festivals and Marketing

Take a look at our Perks (what you receive for supporting the project) and then make some noise about "Jane" on social media! Every little bit helps!

THANK YOU!

story: Hello! My name is Jenny. I am an actor in Los Angeles, CA and need your help, so please continue reading :)  I am currently putting together a new acting demo reel. A demo reel is a video collaboration of your past acting roles to show your type/talent. However, most of my past roles are from short films/student films and don't provide me with enough footage or good quality footage. SO instead ofjust waiting to be cast in roles, hoping the footage is usable and spending years trying to collect enough good quality clips of my material for a reel, I've decided I'll just write the roles myself. Because in this industry if you're not CREATING, than you're just WAITING.The acting reel I currently have is 99% from a webseries I co-wrote and funded myself last year. (You can watch that at the end of the video on this page.) However it is not nearly enough footage for a reel, so I am currently working on filming a few NEW scenes to add. Even with help from my family, I am short on budget. I've hired a crew that consists of sound, lighting, camera and director, and have reached my maximum amount of spending. BUT I STILL NEED A LOCATION TO FILM! What good is a crew and a script, if you have no where to make the magic happen! In order to make these scenes the best quality possible, I plan on filming at a sound stage with actual sets. I've spent hours researching places and now I need your help! This reel could really help advance my career and I'd love any amount you could help out with!

story:
AYÚDANOS A CONCLUIR!

HELP US FINISH!

ES | Ayudanos a terminar este documental de memoria sobre el Campamento por la Paz durante 2016 y sobre la paz de Colombia.
EN | Ais us in finishing our documentary about the Peace Camp of 2016 in Bogotá, Colombia. 


NUESTRO CUENTO

OUR STORY

ES | Todo comienza con el proceso de paz que cierra su acuerdo con una firma final tras medio siglo de violencia. El plebiscito del 2 de octubre de 2016, que debía refrendar los acuerdos falló, al recibir recibió una sorprendente votación mayor por el ‘No’ con un margen muy estrecho (0.4%). Tras la desilusión colectiva, los más resilientes decidieron, como acto cívico y de forma simbólica, tomarse la Plaza de Bolívar tras la  'Tercera Marcha del Silencio' del 5 de Octubre, que acampando y resistiendo durante 45 noches; exigieron al Gobierno y las FARC mantener el cese al fuego de manera indefinida y trabajar en la pronta firma de unos nuevos acuerdos.

Pasados tres días de la fundación del Campamento por la Paz, decidimos como colectivo, y por cercanía a algunos de los campistas, encaminarnos a la Plaza a registrar parte del acontecimiento y solidarizarnos con esta idea de toma del espacio público que nos llamó la atención. Jamás esperamos encontrarnos con un espacio tan diverso de personas, provenientes de diferentes regiones del país, con diferentes edades y creencias. Nos encontramos con una pequeña Colombia que nos recibía con brazos abiertos, aguapanela y pan.

Así, decidimos quedarnos hasta el final, sabiendo que ese espacio era importante para el país y que allí ocurrían cosas importantes y dignas de volver a contar. De esta decisión sale este documental y las ganas de resistir, en unión a un objetivo común: la paz de Colombia.

ES | (TRANSLATION PENDING)

 

EN QUÉ VAMOS

WERE WE ARE AT

ES | Nuestro proceso de producción fue espontáneo. Hicimos diariamente un registro del Campamento Por La Paz durante 51 noches mientras participamos en él. Contamos con más de 400 horas de video, fotos y material de apoyo para los testimonios.. Tenemos la idea principal y la estructura base de la cual partir para contar nuestro cuento. (Propuesta Escrita del Proyecto)

EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)

LO QUE FALTA

WHAT IS NEEDED

ES | Ahora nos encontramos en el proceso de postproducción, recolectando memoria de entrevistas un año después y revisando nuestro material. Debemos cubrir los costos de guión, edición, musicalización, mezcla sonora, masterización, colorización y distribución.

EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)

POR QUÉ AYUDARNOS?

WHY HELP US

ES | Es importante hacer parte de la memoria colectiva del país con el registro que tenemos de este suceso. No permitir que quede olvidado como tantos otros movimientos sociales que a diferencia de este, a pesar de todo, cumplió con su objetivo principal.  Creemos que después de un año el país sigue en un proceso de paz tan importante como frágil, que día a día exige conciencia del pueblo colombiano; tal vez sea un momento adecuado para seguir contribuyendo a la reflexión sobre el asunto, pensar hacia dónde va nuestro país y cómo podemos aportar a este proceso de paz que a gritos pide nuestro pueblo, habiendo superado las decepciones de los fallos.

EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)

QUIÉNES SOMOS? / WHO WE ARE

ES | Somos parte de La Bogotá sin Asco, un proyecto que pretende darle una mirada característica a Bogotá. Dentro de nuestros objetivos está la lucha por la paz y la igualdad, por una Bogotá y una Colombia con menos discriminación, más tolerante y menos polarizada, así como documentar la ciudad y sus procesos.

EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)

El Dream Team: Lina Umaña F, Maria Fernanda Guerrero, Simón D. Hampton

 

PH: FRANCISCO JOSE JAVIER CUADROS

Debemos cubrir los costos de guión, edición, musicalización, mezcla sonora, masterización, colorización y distribución.EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)POR QUÉ AYUDARNOS?WHY HELP USES | Es importante hacer parte de la memoria colectiva del país con el registro que tenemos de este suceso. No permitir que quede olvidado como tantos otros movimientos sociales que a diferencia de este, a pesar de todo, cumplió con su objetivo principal.  Creemos que después de un año el país sigue en un proceso de paz tan importante como frágil, que día a día exige conciencia del pueblo colombiano; tal vez sea un momento adecuado para seguir contribuyendo a la reflexión sobre el asunto, pensar hacia dónde va nuestro país y cómo podemos aportar a este proceso de paz que a gritos pide nuestro pueblo, habiendo superado las decepciones de los fallos.EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)QUIÉNES SOMOS? / WHO WE AREES | Somos parte de La Bogotá sin Asco, un proyecto que pretende darle una mirada característica a Bogotá. Dentro de nuestros objetivos está la lucha por la paz y la igualdad, por una Bogotá y una Colombia con menos discriminación, más tolerante y menos polarizada, así como documentar la ciudad y sus procesos.EN | (TRANSLATION PENDING)El Dream Team: Lina Umaña F, Maria Fernanda Guerrero, Simón D. Hampton PH: FRANCISCO JOSE JAVIER CUADROS

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

  • I'm a senior in the film and television program at NYU Tisch. I've written and directed a number of short films. I've also interned at Red Hour Films and Penguin Random House.
  • This poetic, loosely narrative short film aims to explore humanity's relationship with nature, and our responsibility to the Earth. While this film is about the end of the world, it is ultimately full of hope and appreciation for our planet. 
  • Your support and contributions are vital to this production, and will mean so much to the entire team behind this film.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $3,800 in total to make this film. We've been awarded an allotment of $800 from NYU. The remaining $3,000 in donations will go towards crucial aspects of production, including location, transportation, food, equipment rentals and production design.
  • Contributors will receive exclusive merchandise, credit in the film, and more!
  • Since this film focuses so heavily on nature and the environment, location is the priority! So, if we don't reach our entire goal, funds will be allocated to location first.

Budget Breakdown

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Donate food, props or other necessities (contact Hannah directly for details)
  • Please share this page wherever possible!

Your support and contributions are vital to this production, and will mean so much to the entire team behind this film.


What We Need & What You Get

We need $3,800 in total to make this film. We've been awarded an allotment of $800 from NYU. The remaining $3,000 in donations will go towards crucial aspects of production, including location, transportation, food, equipment rentals and production design.
Contributors will receive exclusive merchandise, credit in the film, and more!
Since this film focuses so heavily on nature and the environment, location is the priority! So, if we don't reach our entire goal, funds will be allocated to location first.

Please share this page wherever possible!

story:
The Story

Drag queens. Hit men. Drug deals. Romance. We’re not talking about the newest season of NCIS: New Orleans, but a new short film out of Boston University’s film production program: Honey and Jerome Forever!

Borne from a love for the campy works of John Waters, the melodrama of classic “bad movies” like Showgirls, and the artistry of drag, writer and director Annalise Lamberty began writing Honey and Jerome Forever! almost a year ago in an attempt to bring some color to the average student film repertoire. Centering around Honey Velvet, a young drag queen, and her boyfriend Jerome, this film asks the audience: how do you pick between love and livelihood?

With cult cinema subject matter and super stylized visuals, the Honey and Jerome Forever! team hopes to create a film that can only be described as “meaningfully campy” - fun and over-the-top, but still impactful and politically significant. We believe that a step towards equal representation of people of color and the LGBT community in film and TV starts with us, a diverse cast and crew, telling a fun story that everyone can get into.

The People

                  

Annalise Lamberty

A Midwestern native transplanted to the East Coast, Annalise Lamberty is a senior at Boston University studying film and concentrating in writing and directing. After realizing traditional drama and social realism wasn’t her style, Annalise embraced the campiness and melodrama of iconic directors like John Waters and Pedro Almodovar and began to write Honey and Jerome Forever! With a particular passion for gritty visuals and stylized production design, Annalise is excited to direct a film that showcases the charisma, uniqueness, nerve, and talent of the LGBT community.

Grace Condon

Grace Condon is a senior at Boston University studying Film with a capital F. Her passions include writing and performing stand up comedy, and producing. Grace is so excited to be producing Honey And Jerome Forever! because of its dark humor, involvement of Drag culture, and campy nature. She hopes to help bring out the humor in Honey and Jerome Forever! while smooth talking her way into getting the best actors, donations, and locations for this film. Like, seriously, she'll shave off her left eyebrow if it will make this film better. (DIRECTOR’S NOTE: This will, unequivocally, make the film better.)

Bobby Li

A senior at Boston University, Bobby Li discovered his visual talents from the first time he picked up a camera 4 years ago. He immediately fell in love with it and decided to study film and advertising. Bobby believes that as a cinematographer, he is a storyteller just as the director is but only through lighting and camera. In Honey and Jerome Forever!, Bobby Li will build the drag world through lighting and production design. Bobby is ready to spend countless hours in order to vividly capture this world. 

Teddy Qi

Teddy Qi is the production designer of Honey and Jerome Forever! She is in charge of designing sets, locations, props, costumes, and make-up. Honey and Jerome Forever! requires great amount of design in order to give the audience the authentic feeling of being in a real drag club, which makes it fun and challenging job for her.

Ran Shan

Ran Shan is a senior in Boston University majoring in film production. She was studying biochem until she found her true love in film. She’s worked on a few professional feature film sets as well as many students film sets. She’s experienced and involved in all parts of filmmaking, and production design is the one where her passions lie. When she was back in China, she loved to spend her time in an old art studio doing oil painting and sculpture. Production design gives her more room to play with the colors and details that will make this film great.

Deijah Lee-Carroll

Deijah Lee-Carroll is a senior in the film and television program at Boston University who wants nothing more than to surround herself with computer monitors and editing software. She loves food, curly hair products, and telling the stories of those often overlooked by the mainstream media (hence her excitement to work on Honey and Jerome Forever!) With a desire to be simultaneously lowkey and extra, she truly hopes her editing will portray the magic and beauty of drag.

The Budget

We're looking to raise $6,000, mainly to be used for cinematography equipment and production design.   

Camera and Lighting: In order to accurately portray stylized club lighting and the intense color scheme Bobby is designing, we need specialized equipment not offered at Boston University. We're investing in tools like a polarizer, wireless follow-focus, and an external recorder. 

Set Dressing/Makeup and Wardrobe: These two categories make up almost half of our budget because they're important to creating a believable, lived-in world. This section of our budget goes to props, set design and building, costuming, drag padding, wigs, and makeup artistry that Teddy and Ran have in mind.

Locations: Because we wanted to have as much control as possible over the setting we're shooting in, we're shooting in a studio space and building our set from the ground-up. This section of our budget is dedicated to the rental costs for the studio we'll be filming in.

Food/On-Set Costs: With an estimated 6 days of shooting, we need to keep our cast and crew fed (and thus, happy). Alongside that, we never know what might come up during a shoot - making a battery or extension cord run, buying superglue to fix a prop, or even picking up straws so the queens don't ruin their lipstick - so these budget sections are for cast and crew maintenance.

Transportation: We'll be renting a UHaul to truck our equipment and production design elements to and from the studio space we're shooting in, and we'll also be providing transportation or reimbursement for our actors who may need to commute to set. Our transportation budget is for UHaul rental, travel reimbursement, Uber/Lyft rides for cast and crew, and gas expenses. 

The Risks

Like all filmmaking ventures, Honey and Jerome Forever! comes with risks on- and off-set. Practically, Professor Sam Kauffmann at Boston University is advising us on risk prevention and management so our set will be the safest it can be; additionally, we are able to obtain location insurance through Boston University's film department, should we need it. Off-set, we are carefully planning our budget to make sure each department and each performer receives their agreed upon amount - we won't be using your donations for anything shady. Finally, in terms of working as a crew, we are all committed to fostering an environment of inclusion and open communication to make this shoot as smooth as possible.

story:
WE NEED YOU

Setting the Word on Fire takes on the xenophobic, nationalist and racist rhetoric permeating our national discourse using literature, images and a call to action.  We have completed principal photography and our goal now is to raise $30,000 to cover editing costs and complete a 90-minute cut.  We believe this film is urgently needed and that it is critical we complete post-production as soon as possible. Your contribution will help us to do this!

   

Setting the Word on Fire contributes to the rich tradition of nonfiction filmmaking that speaks truth to power and bolsters struggles for social change. The Labor, Civil Rights, Peace, Environmental, Women’s Liberation and LGBT movements have all been rooted in social justice activism and our main protagonist, Alejandro Murguia, has been profoundly influenced by these movements. As one of the internationally known “Mission Poets,” along with such writers as Roberto Vargas, Nina Serrano and U.S. Poet Laureate Juan Felipe Herrera, Murguia carries forward the tradition of politically engaged writers including Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Federico Garcia Lorca, Ernest Hemmingway, Pablo Neruda, and Ernesto Cardenal. 

The winner of two American Book Awards and Poet Laureate of San Francisco, Murguia writes about first-hand experiences and observations: from his participation in the Chicano and anti-war movements in Los Angeles to his months on the battlefield with the Sandinistas in Nicaragua, his early days in San Francisco with Ferlinghetti and the Beat Poets and recently in the national fight against gentrification. While much of what Murguia has written about over the last forty years is rooted in the Latino experience, his work continues to inspire people all over the world to speak truth to power through literature and to continue in their struggles for social justice.

PLEASE SHARE OUR LINK

In addition to your financial support, you can help us by sharing this link and spreading the word about Setting the Word on Fire with your network of friends, family, colleagues and contacts who are passionate about films like ours. Thank you for joining us on this important journey!

If you would like to make a donation of any amount and don't need a perk in return, just click BACK IT in the upper righthand corner and make your donation.  Thanks!

 

OUR TEAM

Director/ Producer

Raymond Telles’ thirty-five year career in film and television includes the production of numerous documentaries and segments for PBS, ABC, NBC, National Geographic, Discovery and Univision.” Among the honors these programs have received are the Columbia DuPont, Peabody, Emmy and Alma awards.

Director/Producer

David L. Brown has produced, written and directed over 80 productions and 14 broadcast documentaries, mostly on issues of social justice and healthy aging.  His documentaries have received over 85 international awards including three Emmy Awards and have been broadcast on PBS and in sixteen other countries.

Producer

Louis F. Dematteis came to filmmaking by way of an award-winning career as a photojournalist and documentary photographer. He covers issues of social, political and environmental importance, and his award-winning films include the documentary "Crimebuster: A Son’s Search for His Father" and the narrative feature "The Other Barrio".

Director of Photography

Vicente Franco was a 2003 Oscar nominee for Best Documentary and Emmy nominee for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography for "Daughter from Danang", winner of the Sundance Film Festival 2002 Grand Jury Prize. He won the Silver Apple/Latin American Studies Association for "Cuba Va: the Challenge of the Next Generation".

story:
Short Summary

  • Majoring in cinematography.
  • I want to make a film with my friends from SVA that can show all of the talents that everyone has learned while in school.
  • This project can't happen without the support of you. Every donation is the biggest help for the production; helping feed the crew, transportation, props, etc... 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The goal for my thesis, "Pop Pop" is $5,000. Most of the expenses will be broken down to cover every aspect of the production and post-production.
  • Everyone who donates will benefit from different perks to say "Thank You!" for supporting the project from the beginning.
  • If we don't make the goal of $5,000, the project will still go on with a few cut corners to make up for the difference. Every size donation helps a ton and is appreciated by the whole crew.

"Starving artist" is a saying that many people have heard of, but have you heard of "Starving filmmaker"? In my opinion, creating a film can be very expensive to cover some of the many corners of the production. Wanting to make sure everyone in the crew and cast are taken care of and that any supplies that would be needed to make a smoother workflow are available to the production. 

  • Everyone who donates will be included in the credits of the film under "Special Thanks" with your full name.
  • Since 2014, I have made one film each year with increasing skill in each new film, applying what I have learned in film school, leading all the way up to my biggest project yet, this one!
  • I'm always amazed by what students make during their thesis year at SVA create. Putting creative minds together and after a year of hard work, the films are screened in front of hundreds of people with seamless effort and it is a beautiful thing. I want to try my best to give the same thing to my friends and family with this project.

Risks & Challenges

A common phrase in the film industry is that "anything that can go wrong, will go wrong" on a film set. Obstacles do arise and unexpected expenses pop up in what seems to be the most inconvenient of times. But with a well-planned production, even things like that can be handled as a team if the support is there.

  • Since I was a freshman, I tried helping as many friends on their film sets as I could to learn. Seeing what my friends would have to do to fix a problem or try alternative ideas on set, have really taught me first-hand experience while also applying what I have learned in production class.
  • Communication and honesty among the crew and production of this thesis film are vital to having a comfortable workflow and hurdle challenges together if they come up.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Being in college, money is tight, I understand not everyone has the extra dough laying around, but you can also help this film come to life by sharing this campaign with friends or family! It helps tremendously!
  • Sharing the campaign on social media is easy! Just use the share tabs provided with the indiegogo.

I'm always amazed by what students make during their thesis year at SVA create. Putting creative minds together and after a year of hard work, the films are screened in front of hundreds of people with seamless effort and it is a beautiful thing. I want to try my best to give the same thing to my friends and family with this project.

A common phrase in the film industry is that "anything that can go wrong, will go wrong" on a film set. Communication and honesty among the crew and production of this thesis film are vital to having a comfortable workflow and hurdle challenges together if they come up.

story:
Autumn Leaves born in August 2016  by a Gian Marco Castro and Ludovica Ingallina's idea.

The project includes a short film's production where the theme is death caused by cancer. We chose this sensitive theme because in Sicily, expecially in Augusta, Priolo and Melilli (Triangle of death), every year there is a high rate of mortality caused by industries.

 

 

You will ever happen when you finish to see a film that you start to think how the actors, director, screenplay and costumers were amazing... And what about the Soundtrack? That's what usually happen in many film.

They have a lot of potential, but they're poorly in the music. We are taking care of every single particular of our short film. We decide to start from the soundtrack because one of the most important things for us is the impact of the music in the scenes.

 The scenes and the music are strongly connected to each other in this movie. The music will be the background to the scenes, it will be sweet and melancholic accompaniment which will make the emotional scenes unforgettable in the eyes of those who look.

Another particularity of our short film is that is mute, what means mute? Without word and dialogs between the characters. We will take attention in the gesture and the expression of the look.

-We decide to create a mute short film too because we would like to break down the barriers between the languages, in this way the short film will be understandable for everyone-.

First sheet music page

 

Autumn Leaves is a story about love, life and pain.

It's inspired by real events, the story recalls, in a short time, some important phases of main characters's life: a man and woman with her baby, they are dragged inside a vortex of memories unleashing some important moments in them, these moments will understand them the life's deep religious sense.

 

 

 

Autumn Leaves is the english translation of "Foglie d'autunno".

The autumn in this story is a symbolic figure, it represents the season where everything dies but at the same time it represent the grape harvest's season but despite decadence that happens, autumn represents something of positive.

Leaves had an important role during the whole short film's creation because they represent leaves that will fall on the floor and all people who lost their lives fighting, leaves still present on the branches will represent women, men and kids who fight for healing by this disease.

 

 

 

 

The short film has a small, intimate cast of people that focuses primarily to sensitize on the desease of our century.

 

Carmelo Fazio - Director and Screenwriter

Carmelo Fazio (22 September, 1983) he attended Art Academy in Catania. Director of different promotional spot, music video and "Fuffy" the Webserie.

 

Ludovica Ingallina - Creator and Screewnwriter

Ludovica ingallina (5 April, 1996) she studies languages at university in Catania. Actually she writes on the page Delilah (Facebook). 

Delilah Page

 

Andrea Fazio - Editor and Director of Photography

Andrea Fazio (1 February, 1988) he is graduated at sciences high School. He is a video editor and director of photography for different promotional spot, music video and "Fuffy" the Webserie.

 

Gian Marco Castro - Composer and Producer

Gian Marco Castro (16 Dicember, 1995) he studies at Bellini Conservatory in Catania. He is a Film Composer, recently he has recieved a nomination at Hollywood Music in Media Awards.

Gian Marco Castro On Imdb

 

Marco Castellani - Visual Effect

Marco Castellani is known for his work on Guardians of  the Galaxy  (2014), Into Darkness - Star Trek  (2013) and John Carter   (2012). 

Marco Castellani On Imdb

 

Andrea Orto - Art Director

Andrea Orto It's a cartoonist, he live in Germany, Illustrator for "Like me Like a Joker" the Webserie.

 

Francesco Siscaro - Sound Supervisor

Francesco Siscaro aka Ace4Noize study at Bellini Conservatory in Catania, he work like producer and sound designer.

 

Nico Cirillo - Executive Producer

Nico Cirillo will be the promoter for our Short Film, It's a Radio Conductor for Radio Musmea.

 

Luigi Sciuti - Associate Producer 

Luigi Sciuti is graduated at sciences high School, will be the promoter and marketing manager for our Short Film.

 

 

 

 

The Budget:  With your special help we will afford all the things that we need to realize the short film, things like: rent out Cameras, set, costumers, location and all the musicians for record the soundtrack, technicians, set crew's and the post production process!

We need your helpt too for sending the short film in different competitions like: Sundance film festival, Cannes and the Academy.

9500$ it's che magic number that will help us to find professional actors, many of them live abroad, so we need money for pay them the lodging or the airplan, if they need to take it!

For the main character of our short film we choose one of the best actress in the italian film scene she has recieved two nomination at David of Donatello and she has acted in the "La Grande Bellezza" - "Great Beauty",  Academy Winner  in 2014 as a foreign best film. We have yet two actors but the number of the character in the short film is 4. When we will reach the agread amount we will publish the official characters cast of Autumn Leaves with pictures and biography.

 

 

We have two Secret Perks with a secret Link! Contact us if you want an exclusive and personal perk!

 

WE HOPE FOR YOUR HELP

 

THANK YOU BACKERS!

 

 

Official Poster of Autumn Leaves
